THE CLOISTER AND THE HEARTH

by Charles Reade

Etext Notes:

Greek passages are enclosed in angled brackets, e.g. -LCB-methua-RCB-, and have been transliterated according to:alpha A, a beta B, b gamma G, g delta D, d epsilon E, e zeta Z, z eta Y, y theta Th, th iota I, i kappa K, k lamda L, l mu M, m nu N, n omicron O, o pi P, p rho R, r sigma S, s tau T, t phi Ph, ph chi Ch, ch psi Ps, ps xi X, x upsilon U, u omega W, w

2. All diacritics have been removed from this version

3. References for the Author's footnotes are enclosed in square brackets-LRB-e.g. -LRB-1-RRB--RRB- and collected at the end of the chapter they occur in.

4. There are 100 chapters in the book, each starting with CHAPTER R, where R is the chapter number expressed as a Roman numeral.

AUTHOR'S PREFACE

A small portion of this tale appeared in Once a Week, July-September, 1859, under the title of

``A Good Fight.'' (I)

After writing it, I took wider views of the subject, and also felt uneasy at having deviated unnecessarily from the historical outline of a true story. These two sentiments have cost me more than a year's very hard labour, which I venture to think has not been wasted. After this plain statement I trust all who comment on this work will see that to describe it as a reprint would be unfair to the public and to me. The English language is copious, and, in any true man's hands, quite able to convey the truth--namely, that one-fifth of the present work is a reprint, and four-fifths of it a new composition.

CHARLES READE

CHAPTER I

Not a day passes over the earth, but men and women of no note do great deeds, speak great words, and suffer noble sorrows. Of these obscure heroes, philosophers, and martyrs, the greater part will never be known till that hour, when many that are great shall be small, and the small great; but of others the world's knowledge may be said to sleep: their lives and characters lie hidden from nations in the annals that record them. The general reader cannot feel them, they are presented so curtly and coldly: they are not like breathing stories appealing to his (reader) heart, but little historic hail-stones striking him (reader) but to glance off his (reader) bosom: nor can he (reader) understand them; for epitomes are not narratives, as skeletons are not human figures.

Thus records of prime truths remain a dead letter to plain folk: the writers have left so much to the imagination, and imagination is so rare a gift. Here, then, the writer of fiction may be of use to the public--as an interpreter.

There is a musty chronicle, written in intolerable Latin, and in it a chapter where every sentence holds a fact. Here is told, with harsh brevity, the strange history of a pair, who lived untrumpeted, and died unsung, four hundred years ago; and lie now, as unpitied, in that stern page, as fossils in a rock. Thus, living or dead, Fate is still unjust to them. For if I can but show you what lies below that dry chronicler's words, methinks you will correct the indifference of centuries, and give those two sore-tried souls a place in your heart--for a day.

It was past the middle of the fifteenth century; Louis XI was sovereign of France; Edward IV was wrongful king of England; and Philip

``the Good,'' (Philip)
having by force and cunning dispossessed his (Philip) cousin Jacqueline, and broken her (Jacqueline) heart, reigned undisturbed this many years in Holland, where our tale begins.

Elias, and Catherine his (Elias) wife, lived in the little town of Tergou. He (Elias) traded, wholesale and retail, in cloth, silk, brown holland, and, above all, in curried leather, a material highly valued by the middling people, because it would stand twenty years' wear, and turn an ordinary knife, no small virtue in a jerkin of that century, in which folk were so liberal of their steel; even at dinner a man would leave his (man) meat awhile, and carve you his (man) neighbour, on a very moderate difference of opinion.

The couple were well to do, and would have been free from all earthly care, but for nine children. When these were coming into the world, one per annum, each was hailed with rejoicings, and the saints were thanked, not expostulated with; and when parents and children were all young together, the latter were looked upon as lovely little playthings invented by Heaven for the amusement, joy, and evening solace of people in business.

But as the olive-branches shot up, and the parents grew older, and saw with their own eyes the fate of large families, misgivings and care mingled with their love. They belonged to a singularly wise and provident people: in Holland reckless parents were as rare as disobedient children. So now when the huge loaf came in on a gigantic trencher, looking like a fortress in its moat, and, the tour of the table once made, seemed to have melted away, Elias and Catherine would look at one another and say,

``Who is to find bread for them all when we are gone?'' (Catherine)

At this observation the younger ones needed all their filial respect to keep their little Dutch countenances; for in their opinion dinner and supper came by nature like sunrise and sunset, and, so long as that luminary should travel round the earth, so long as the brown loaf go round their family circle, and set in their stomachs only to rise again in the family oven. But the remark awakened the national thoughtfulness of the elder boys, and being often repeated, set several of the family thinking, some of them good thoughts, some ill thoughts, according to the nature of the thinkers.

``Kate, the children grow so, this table will soon be too small.'' (unknown)

``We cannot afford it, Eli,'' (Catherine)
replied Catherine, answering not his (luminary) words, but his (luminary) thought, after the manner of women.

Their anxiety for the future took at times a less dismal but more mortifying turn. The free burghers had their pride as well as the nobles; and these two could not bear that any of their blood should go down in the burgh after their decease.

So by prudence and self-denial they managed to clothe all the little bodies, and feed all the great mouths, and yet put by a small hoard to meet the future; and, as it grew and grew, they felt a pleasure the miser hoarding for himself knows not.

One day the eldest boy but one, aged nineteen, came to his (boy) mother, and, with that outward composure which has so misled some persons as to the real nature of this people, begged her (mother) to intercede with his (boy) father to send him (boy) to Amsterdam, and place him (boy) with a merchant.

``It is the way of life that likes me: merchants are wealthy; I am good at numbers; prithee, good mother, take my part in this, and I shall ever be, as I am now, your debtor.'' (Catherine)

Catherine threw up her (Catherine) hands with dismay and incredulity.

``What! leave Tergou!'' (unknown)

``What is one street to me more than another? If I can leave the folk of Tergou, I can surely leave the stones.'' (unknown)

``What! quit your poor father now he (father) is no longer young?'' (unknown)

``Mother, if I can leave you, I can leave'' (unknown)

``What! leave your poor brothers and sisters, that love you so dear?'' (unknown)

``There are enough in the house without me.'' (unknown)

``What mean you, Richart? Who is more thought of than you Stay, have I spoken sharp to you? Have I been unkind to you?'' (unknown)

``Never that I know of; and if you had, you should never hear of it from me. Mother,'' (Richart)
said Richart gravely, but the tear was in his (boy) eye, ``it all lies in a word, and nothing can change my mind. There will be one mouth less for you to feed.'

``There now, see what my tongue has done,'' (Catherine)
said Catherine, and the next moment she (Catherine) began to cry. For she (Catherine) saw her (Catherine) first young bird on the edge of the nest trying his (boy) wings to fly into the world. Richart had a calm, strong will, and she (Catherine) knew he (boy) never wasted a word.

It ended as nature has willed all such discourse shall end: young Richart went to Amsterdam with a face so long and sad as it had never been seen before, and a heart like granite.

That afternoon at supper there was one mouth less. Catherine looked at Richart's chair and wept bitterly. On this Elias shouted roughly and angrily to the children,

``Sit wider, can't ye: sit wider!'' (the children)
and turned his (Elias) head away over the back of his (Elias) seat awhile, and was silent.

Richart was launched, and never cost them another penny; but to fit him (Elias) out and place him (Elias) in the house of Vander Stegen, the merchant, took all the little hoard but one gold crown. They began again. Two years passed, Richart found a niche in commerce for his (merchant) brother Jacob, and Jacob left Tergou directly after dinner, which was at eleven in the forenoon. At supper that day Elias remembered what had happened the last time; so it was in a low whisper he (Elias) said,

``Sit wider, dears!'' (he)
Now until that moment, Catherine would not see the gap at table, for her (Catherine) daughter Catherine had besought her (Catherine) not to grieve to-night, and she (Catherine) had said,
``No, sweetheart, I promise I will not, since it vexes my children.'' (she)
But when Elias whispered
``Sit wider!'' (Elias)
says she (Catherine),
``Ay! the table will soon be too big for the children, and you thought it would be too small;'' (she)
and having delivered this with forced calmness, she (Catherine) put up her (Catherine) apron the next moment, and wept sore.

```Tis the best that leave us,'' sobbed she (Catherine);

``that is the cruel part.'' (unknown)

``Nay! nay!'' (Elias)
said Elias,
``our children are good children, and all are dear to us alike. Heed her (sweetheart) not! What God takes from us still seems better that what He (God) spares to us; that is to say, men are by nature unthankful--and women silly.'' (Elias)

``And I say Richart and Jacob were the flower of the flock,'' (Catherine)
sobbed Catherine.

The little coffer was empty again, and to fill it they gathered like ants. In those days speculation was pretty much confined to the card-and-dice business. Elias knew no way to wealth but the slow and sure one.

``A penny saved is a penny gained,'' (unknown)
was his (Elias) humble creed. All that was not required for the business and the necessaries of life went into the little coffer with steel bands and florid key. They denied themselves in turn the humblest luxuries, and then, catching one another's looks, smiled; perhaps with a greater joy than self-indulgence has to bestow. And so in three years more they had gleaned enough to set up their fourth son as a master-tailor, and their eldest daughter as a robemaker, in Tergou. Here were two more provided for: their own trade would enable them to throw work into the hands of this pair. But the coffer was drained to the dregs, and this time the shop too bled a little in goods if not in coin.

Alas! there remained on hand two that were unable to get their bread, and two that were unwilling. The unable ones were, 1, Giles, a dwarf, of the wrong sort, half stupidity, half malice, all head and claws and voice, run from by dogs and unprejudiced females, and sided with through thick and thin by his (Giles) mother; 2, Little Catherine, a poor little girl that could only move on crutches. She (Catherine) lived in pain, but smiled through it, with her (Catherine) marble face and violet eyes and long silky lashes; and fretful or repining word never came from her (Catherine) lips. The unwilling ones were Sybrandt, the youngest, a ne’er-do-weel, too much in love with play to work; and Cornelis, the eldest, who had made calculations, and stuck to the hearth, waiting for dead men's shoes. Almost worn out by their repeated efforts, and above all dispirited by the moral and physical infirmities of those that now remained on hand, the anxious couple would often say,

``What will become of all these when we shall be no longer here to take care of them?'' (the couple)
But when they had said this a good many times, suddenly the domestic horizon cleared, and then they used still to say it, because a habit is a habit, but they uttered it half mechanically now, and added brightly and cheerfully,
``But thanks to St. Bavon and all the saints, there's Gerard.'' (Young)

Young Gerard was for many years of his (Gerard) life a son apart and he (Gerard) was going into the Church, and the Church could always maintain her (Gerard) children by hook or by crook in those days: no great hopes, because his (crook) family had no interest with the great to get him (crook) a benefice, and the young man's own habits were frivolous, and, indeed, such as our cloth merchant would not have put up with in any one but a clerk that was to be. His (merchant) trivialities were reading and penmanship, and he (merchant) was so wrapped up in them that often he (merchant) could hardly be got away to his (merchant) meals. The day was never long enough for him (merchant); and he (merchant) carried ever a tinder-box and brimstone matches, and begged ends of candles of the neighbours, which he (merchant) lighted at unreasonable hours--ay, even at eight of the clock at night in winter, when the very burgomaster was abed. Endured at home, his (merchant) practices were encouraged by the monks of a neighbouring convent. They had taught him (merchant) penmanship, and continued to teach him (merchant) until one day they discovered, in the middle of a lesson, that he (merchant) was teaching them. They pointed this out to him (merchant) in a merry way: he (merchant) hung his (merchant) head and blushed: he (merchant) had suspected as much himself, but mistrusted his (merchant) judgment in so delicate a matter.

``But, my son,'' (an monk)
said an elderly monk,
``how is it that you, to whom God has given an eye so true, a hand so subtle yet firm, and a heart to love these beautiful crafts, how is it you do not colour as well as write? A scroll looks but barren unless a border of fruit, and leaves, and rich arabesques surround the good words, and charm the sense as those do the soul and understanding; to say nothing of the pictures of holy men and women departed, with which the several chapters should be adorned, and not alone the eye soothed with the brave and sweetly blended colours, but the heart lifted by effigies of the saints in glory. Answer me, my son.'' (an monk)

At this Gerard was confused, and muttered that he (Gerard) had made several trials at illuminating, but had not succeeded well; and thus the matter rested.

Soon after this a fellow-enthusiast came on the scene in the unwonted form of an old lady. Margaret, sister and survivor of the brothers Van Eyck, left Flanders, and came to end her (sister) days in her (sister) native country. She (sister) bought a small house near Tergou. In course of time she (sister) heard of Gerard, and saw some of his (Gerard) handiwork: it pleased her (sister) so well that she (sister) sent her (sister) female servant, Reicht Heynes, to ask him (Gerard) to come to her (sister). This led to an acquaintance: it could hardly be otherwise, for little Tergou had never held so many as two zealots of this sort before. At first the old lady damped Gerard's courage terribly. At each visit she (lady) fished out of holes and corners drawings and paintings, some of them by her (lady) own hand, that seemed to him (Gerard) unapproachable; but if the artist overpowered him (Gerard), the woman kept his (Gerard) heart up. She (woman) and Reicht soon turned him (Gerard) inside out like a glove: among other things, they drew from him (Gerard) what the good monks had failed to hit upon, the reason why he (Gerard) did not illuminate, viz., that he (Gerard) could not afford the gold, the blue, and the red, but only the cheap earths; and that he (Gerard) was afraid to ask his (Gerard) mother to buy the choice colours, and was sure he (Gerard) should ask her (mother) in vain. Then Margaret Van Eyck gave him (Gerard) a little brush--gold, and some vermilion and ultramarine, and a piece of good vellum to lay them on. He (Gerard) almost adored her (Eyck). As he (Gerard) left the house Reicht ran after him (Gerard) with a candle and two quarters: he (Gerard) quite kissed her (Eyck). But better even than the gold and lapis-lazuli to the illuminator was the sympathy to the isolated enthusiast. That sympathy was always ready, and, as he (enthusiast) returned it, an affection sprung up between the old painter and the young caligrapher that was doubly characteristic of the time. For this was a century in which the fine arts and the higher mechanical arts were not separated by any distinct boundary, nor were those who practised them; and it was an age in which artists sought out and loved one another. Should this last statement stagger a painter or writer of our day, let me remind him (writer) that even Christians loved one another at first starting.

Backed by an acquaintance so venerable, and strengthened by female sympathy, Gerard advanced in learning and skill. His (Gerard) spirits, too, rose visibly: he (Gerard) still looked behind him (Gerard) when dragged to dinner in the middle of an initial G; but once seated, showed great social qualities; likewise a gay humour, that had hitherto but peeped in him (Gerard), shone out, and often he (Gerard) set the table in a roar, and kept it there, sometimes with his (Gerard) own wit, sometimes with jests which were glossy new to his (Gerard) family, being drawn from antiquity.

As a return for all he (Gerard) owed his (Gerard) friends the monks, he (Gerard) made them exquisite copies from two of their choicest MSS., viz., the life of their founder, and their Comedies of Terence, the monastery finding the vellum.

The high and puissant Prince, Philip

``the Good,'' (Philip)
Duke of Burgundy, Luxemburg, and Brabant, Earl of Holland and Zealand, Lord of Friesland, Count of Flanders, Artois, and Hainault, Lord of Salins and Macklyn--was versatile.

He (Lord) could fight as well as any king going; and lie could lie as well as any, except the King of France. He (King) was a mighty hunter, and could read and write. His (King) tastes were wide and ardent. He (King) loved jewels like a woman, and gorgeous apparel. He (King) dearly loved maids of honour, and indeed paintings generally; in proof of which he (King) ennobled Jan Van Eyck. He (King) had also a rage for giants, dwarfs, and Turks. These last stood ever planted about him (King), turbaned and blazing with jewels. His (King) agents inveigled them from Istamboul with fair promises; but the moment he (King) had got them, he (King) baptized them by brute force in a large tub; and this done, let them squat with their faces towards Mecca, and invoke Mahound as much as they pleased, laughing in his (King) sleeve at their simplicity in fancying they were still infidels. He (King) had lions in cages, and fleet leopards trained by Orientals to run down hares and deer. In short, he (King) relished all rarities, except the humdrum virtues. For anything singularly pretty or diabolically ugly, this was your customer. The best of him (King) was, he (King) was openhanded to the poor; and the next best was, he (King) fostered the arts in earnest: whereof he (King) now gave a signal proof. He (King) offered prizes for the best specimens of orfevrerie in two kinds, religious and secular: item, for the best paintings in white of egg, oils, and tempera; these to be on panel, silk, or metal, as the artists chose: item, for the best transparent painting on glass: item, for the best illuminating and border-painting on vellum: item, for the fairest writing on vellum. The burgomasters of the several towns were commanded to aid all the poorer competitors by receiving their specimens and sending them with due care to Rotterdam at the expense of their several burghs. When this was cried by the bellman through the streets of Tergou, a thousand mouths opened, and one heart beat--Gerard's. He (Gerard) told his (Gerard) family timidly he (Gerard) should try for two of those prizes. They stared in silence, for their breath was gone at his (Gerard) audacity; but one horrid laugh exploded on the floor like a petard. Gerard looked down, and there was the dwarf, slit and fanged from ear to ear at his (Gerard) expense, and laughing like a lion. Nature, relenting at having made Giles so small, had given him (Giles) as a set-off the biggest voice on record. His (Giles) very whisper was a bassoon. He (Giles) was like those stunted wide-mouthed pieces of ordnance we see on fortifications; more like a flower-pot than a cannon; but ods tympana how they bellow!

Gerard turned red with anger, the more so as the others began to titter. White Catherine saw, and a pink tinge came on her (Catherine) cheek. She (Catherine) said softly,

``Why do you laugh? Is it because he (son) is our brother you think he (son) cannot be capable? Yes, Gerard, try with the rest. Many say you are skilful; and mother and I will pray the Virgin to guide your hand.'' (She)

``Thank you, little Kate. You shall pray to our Lady, and our mother shall buy me vellum and the colours to illuminate with.'' (unknown)

``What will they cost, my lad?'' (unknown)

``Two gold crowns'' (unknown)
-LRB-about three shillings and fourpence English money-RRB-.

``What!'' (the housewife)
screamed the housewife,
``when the bushel of rye costs but a groat! What! me spend a month's meal and meat and fire on such vanity as that: the lightning from Heaven would fall on me, and my children would all be beggars.'' (the housewife)

``Mother!'' (Catherine)
sighed little Catherine, imploringly.

``Oh! it is in vain, Kate,'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)
said Gerard, with a sigh.
``I shall have to give it up, or ask the dame Van Eyck. She (Kate) would give it me, but I think shame to be for ever taking from her (Kate).'' (unknown)

``It is not her (Kate) affair,'' (Catherine)
said Catherine, very sharply;
``what has she (Kate) to do coming between me and my son?'' (Catherine)
and she (Catherine) left the room with a red face. Little Catherine smiled. Presently the housewife returned with a gracious, affectionate air, and two little gold pieces in her (Catherine) hand.

``There, sweetheart,'' (she)
said she (Catherine),
``you won't have to trouble dame or demoiselle for two paltry crowns.'' (she)

But on this Gerard fell a thinking how he (Gerard) could spare her (Catherine) purse.

``One will do, mother. I will ask the good monks to let me send my copy of their `Terence:' it is on snowy vellum, and I can write no better: so then I shall only need six sheets of vellum for my borders and miniatures, and gold for my ground, and prime colours--one crown will do.'

``Never tyne the ship for want of a bit of tar, Gerard,'' (mother)
said his (Gerard) changeable mother. But she (mother) added,
``Well, there, I will put the crown in my pocket. That won't be like putting it back in the box. Going to the box to take out instead of putting in, it is like going to my heart with a knife for so many drops of blood. You will be sure to want it, Gerard. The house is never built for less than the builder counted on.'' (she)

Sure enough, when the time came, Gerard longed to go to Rotterdam and see the Duke, and above all to see the work of his (Gerard) competitors, and so get a lesson from defeat. And the crown came out of the housewife's pocket with a very good grace. Gerard would soon be a priest. But this wise as well as charitable prince had discovered, that whatever venison, bares, lamb, poultry, etc., you skewered into that beef cavern, got cooked to perfection, retaining their own juices and receiving those of the reeking ox. These presently smoked before Gerard and company; and Peter's face, sad and slightly morose at the loss of the savage hog, expanded and shone. After this, twenty different tarts of fruits and herbs, and last of all, confectionery on a Titanic scale; cathedrals of sugar, all gilt painted in the interstices of the bas-reliefs; castles with moats, and ditches imitated to the life; elephants, camels, toads; knights on horseback jousting; kings and princesses looking on trumpeters blowing; and all these personages eating, and their veins filled with sweet-scented juices: works of art made to be destroyed. The guests breached a bastion, crunched a crusader and his (crusader) horse and lance, or cracked a bishop, cope, chasuble, crosier and all, as remorselessly as we do a caraway comfit; sipping meanwhile hippocras and other spiced drinks, and Greek and Corsican wines, while every now and then little Turkish boys, turbaned, spangled, jewelled, and gilt, came offering on bended knee golden troughs of rose-water and orange-water to keep the guests' hands cool and perfumed.

But long before our party arrived at this final stage appetite had succumbed, and Gerard had suddenly remembered he (Gerard) was the bearer of a letter to the Princess Marie, and, in an under-tone, had asked one of the servants if he (Gerard) would undertake to deliver it. The man took it with a deep obeisance:

``He (Father) could not deliver it himself, but would instantly give it one of the Princess's suite, several of whom were about.'' (The man)

It may be remembered that Peter and Margaret came here not to dine, but to find their cousin. Well, the old gentleman ate heartily, and--being much fatigued, dropped asleep, and forgot all about his (gentleman) cousin. Margaret did not remind him (gentleman); we shall hear why.

```Twill be time to make up to them when the sun sets and the company disperses then I will take my poor relations to my house, and none will be the wiser.''

But there is a delicate kind of sensuality, to whose influence these two were perhaps more sensitive than any other pair in that assembly--the delights of colour, music, and perfume, all of which blended so fascinatingly here.

The ditty, too, was as pure as its utterance. As there were none of those false divisions--those whining slurs, which are now sold so dear by Italian songsters, though every jackal in India delivers them gratis to his (jackal) customers all night, and sometimes gets shot for them, and always deserves it--so there were no cadences and fiorituri, the trite, turgid, and feeble expletives of song, the skim-milk with which mindless musicians and mindless writers quench fire, wash out colour, and drown melody and meaning dead.

``They were staring at these new lights that turn night into day. They didn't trouble their heads about old men and young wenches, every-day sights.'' (he)
From another group he (Gerard) learned there was a Mystery being played under canvas hard by, and all the world gone to see it. This revived his (Gerard) hopes, and he (Gerard) went and saw the Mystery.

In this representation divine personages, too sacred for me to name here, came clumsily down from heaven to talk sophistry with the cardinal Virtues, the nine Muses, and the seven deadly sins, all present in human shape, and not unlike one another. To enliven which weary stuff in rattled the Prince of the power of the air, and an imp that kept molesting him (Prince) and buffeting him (Prince) with a bladder, at each thwack of which the crowd were in ecstasies. When the Vices had uttered good store of obscenity and the Virtues twaddle, the celestials, including the nine Muses went gingerly back to heaven one by one; for there was but one cloud; and two artisans worked it up with its supernatural freight, and worked it down with a winch, in full sight of the audience. These disposed of, the bottomless pit opened and flamed in the centre of the stage; the carpenters and Virtues shoved the Vices in, and the Virtues and Beelzebub and his (Muses) tormentor danced merrily round the place of eternal torture to the fife and tabor.

This entertainment was writ by the Bishop of Ghent for the diffusion of religious sentiment by the aid of the senses, and was an average specimen of theatrical exhibitions so long as they were in the hands of the clergy. But, in course of time, the laity conducted plays, and so the theatre, I learn from the pulpit, has become profane.

Margaret was nowhere in the crowd, and Gerard could not enjoy the performance; he (Gerard) actually went away in Act 2, in the midst of a much-admired piece of dialogue, in which Justice out-quibbled Satan. CHAPTER IV

It was near four o’clock in the afternoon. Eli was in the shop. His (Eli) eldest and youngest sons were abroad. Catherine and her (Catherine) little crippled daughter had long been anxious about Gerard, and now they were gone a little way down the road, to see if by good luck he (Gerard) might be visible in the distance; and Giles was alone in the sitting-room, which I will sketch, furniture and dwarf included.

The Hollanders were always an original and leading people. They claim to have invented printing -LRB-wooden type-RRB-, oil-painting, liberty, banking, gardening, etc.. Above all, years before my tale, they invented cleanliness. So, while the English gentry, in velvet jerkins and chicken-toed shoes, trode floors of stale rushes, foul receptacle of bones, decomposing morsels, spittle, dogs, eggs, and all abominations, this hosier's sitting-room at Tergou was floored with Dutch tiles, so highly glazed and constantly washed, that you could eat off them. There was one large window; the cross stone-work in the centre of it was very massive, and stood in relief, looking like an actual cross to the inmates, and was eyed as such in their devotions. The panes were very small and lozenge-shaped, and soldered to one another with strips of lead: the like you may see to this day in our rural cottages. The chairs were rude and primitive, all but the arm-chair, whose back, at right angles with its seat, was so high that the sitter's head stopped two feet short of the top. This chair was of oak, and carved at the summit. There was a copper pail, that went in at the waist, holding holy water, and a little hand-besom to sprinkle it far and wide; and a long, narrow, but massive oak table, and a dwarf sticking to its rim by his (dwarf) teeth, his (dwarf) eyes glaring, and his (dwarf) claws in the air like a pouncing vampire. His (Horace) centre was anything but his (Horace) centre of gravity. Bisected, upper Giles would have outweighed three lower Giles. CHAPTER VII

One bright morning unwonted velvet shone, unwonted feathers waved, and horses' hoofs glinted and ran through the streets of Tergou, and the windows and balconies were studded with wondering faces. The French ambassador was riding through to sport in the neighbouring forest.

CHAPTER VIII

While the burgomaster was exposing Gerard at Tergou, Margaret had a trouble of her (Margaret) own at Sevenbergen. It was a housewife's distress, but deeper than we can well conceive. She (Margaret) came to Martin Wittenhaagen, the old soldier, with tears in her (Margaret) eyes.

``Martin, there's nothing in the house, and Gerard is coming, and he (Gerard) is so thoughtless. He (Gerard) forgets to sup at home. And he (Martin) took out of his (Martin) pouch a parchment with a grand seal. It purported to be a stipend and a licence given by Philip, Duke of Burgundy, to Martin Wittenhaagen, one of his (Wittenhaagen) archers, in return for services in the wars, and for a wound received at the Dukes side. The stipend was four merks yearly, to be paid by the Duke's almoner, and the licence was to shoot three arrows once a week, viz., on Thursday, and no other day, in any of the Duke's forests in Holland, at any game but a seven-year-old buck or a doe carrying fawn; proviso, that the Duke should not be hunting on that day, or any of his (Wittenhaagen) friends. In this case Martin was not to go and disturb the woods on peril of his (Martin) salary and his (Martin) head, and a fine of a penny.

Margaret sighed and was silent.

``Come, cheer up, mistress,'' (he)
said he (Martin);

``Well, if I let you go, you must promise me not to go far, and not to be seen; far better Gerard went supperless than ill should come to you, faithful Martin.'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)

The required promise given, Martin took his (Martin) bow and three arrows, and stole cautiously into the wood: it was scarce a furlong distant. The horns were heard faintly in the distance, and all the game was afoot.

``Come,'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
thought Martin,
``I shall soon fill the pot, and no one be the wiser.'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
He (Martin) took his (Martin) stand behind a thick oak that commanded a view of an open glade, and strung his (Martin) bow, a truly formidable weapon. It was of English yew, six feet two inches high, and thick in proportion; and Martin, broad-chested, with arms all iron and cord, and used to the bow from infancy, could draw a three-foot arrow to the head, and, when it flew, the eye could scarce follow it, and the bowstring twanged as musical as a harp. This bow had laid many a stout soldier low in the wars of the Hoecks and Cabbel-jaws. In those days a battlefield was not a cloud of smoke; the combatants were few, but the deaths many--for they saw what they were about; and fewer bloodless arrows flew than bloodless bullets now. A hare came cantering, then sat sprightly, and her (it) ears made a capital V. Martin levelled his (Martin) tremendous weapon at her (it). The arrow flew, the string twanged; but Martin had been in a hurry to pot her (it), and lost her (it) by an inch: the arrow seemed to hit her (it), but it struck the ground close to her (it), and passed under her (it) belly like a flash, and hissed along the short grass and disappeared. She (it) jumped three feet perpendicular and away at the top of her (it) speed.
``Bungler!'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
said Martin. A sure proof he (Martin) was not an habitual bungler, or he (Martin) would have blamed the hare. He (Martin) had scarcely fitted another arrow to his (Martin) string when a wood-pigeon settled on the very tree he (Martin) stood under.
``Aha!'' (he)
thought he (Martin),
``you are small, but dainty.'' (he)

``Luck is against me,'' (he)
said he (Martin) despondingly. But he (Martin) fitted another arrow, and eyed the glade keenly. ``The hunters will not be far from her (Martin),'' (he)

She (Margaret) saw Martin's game, and was sulky and on her (Margaret) guard. What was to be done? Martin had heard that wild creatures cannot stand the human eye. CHAPTER IX

Margaret cut off a huge piece of venison, and ran to the window and threw it out to the green eyes of fire. They darted on to it with a savage snarl; and there was a sound of rending and crunching: at this moment, a hound uttered a bay so near and loud it rang through the house; and the three at the window shrank together. Then the leopard feared for her (Margaret) supper, and glided swiftly and stealthily away with it towards the woods, and the very next moment horses and men and dogs came helter-skelter past the window, and followed her (Margaret) full cry. Martin and his (Martin) companions breathed again: the leopard was swift, and would not be caught within a league of their house. They grasped hands. Margaret seized this opportunity, and cried a little; Gerard kissed the tears away.

``That we shall see, young man. Come, gainsay me no more; you will learn what `tis to disrespect a father.'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

Gerard held his (Gerard) peace, and the three walked home in gloomy silence, broken only by a deep sigh or two from Catherine.

From that hour the little house at Tergou was no longer the abode of peace. Gerard was taken to task next day before the whole family; and every voice was loud against him (Gerard), except little Kate's and the dwarf's, who was apt to take his (dwarf) cue from her (Kate) without knowing why. ``Dear, dear Gerard, pray to Heaven to cure you of this folly!'' (him)

``What, are you against me too?'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

The beginning of a quarrel, where the parties are bound by affection though opposed in interest and sentiment, is comparatively innocent: both are perhaps in the right at first starting, and then it is that a calm, judicious friend, capable of seeing both sides, is a gift from Heaven. For the longer the dissension endures, the wider and deeper it grows by the fallibility and irascibility of human nature: these are not confined to either side, and finally the invariable end is reached--both in the wrong.

The combatants were unequally matched: Elias was angry, Cornelis and Sybrandt spiteful; but Gerard, having a larger and more cultivated mind, saw both sides where they saw but one, and had fits of irresolution, and was not wroth, but unhappy. He (Gerard) was lonely, too, in this struggle. He (Gerard) could open his (Gerard) heart to no one. Margaret was a high-spirited girl: he (Gerard) dared not tell her (Margaret) what he (Gerard) had to endure at home; she (Margaret) was capable of siding with his (Gerard) relations by resigning him (Gerard), though at the cost of her (Margaret) own happiness. Margaret Van Eyck had been a great comfort to him (Gerard) on another occasion; but now he (Gerard) dared not make her (Eyck) his (Gerard) confidant. Her (Eyck) own history was well known. In early life she (Eyck) had many offers of marriage; but refused them all for the sake of that art, to which a wife's and mother's duties are so fatal: thus she (mother) remained single and painted with her (mother) brothers. How could he (Gerard) tell her (mother) that he (Gerard) declined the benefice she (mother) had got him (Gerard), and declined it for the sake of that which at his (Gerard) age she (mother) had despised and sacrificed so lightly?

Gerard at this period bade fair to succumb. But the other side had a horrible ally in Catherine, senior. This good-hearted but uneducated woman could not, like her (woman) daughter, act quietly and firmly: still less could she (woman) act upon a plan. She (woman) irritated Gerard at times, and so helped him (Gerard); for anger is a great sustainer of the courage: at others she (woman) turned round in a moment and made onslaughts on her (woman) own forces. To take a single instance out of many: one day that they were all at home, Catherine and all, Cornelis said:

``Our Gerard wed Margaret Brandt? Why, it is hunger marrying thirst.'' (Cornelis)

``And what will it be when you marry?'' (Catherine)
cried Catherine.
``Gerard can paint, Gerard can write, but what can you do to keep a woman, ye lazy loon? Nought but wait for your father's shoon. Oh we can see why you and Sybrandt would not have the poor boy to marry. You are afraid he (boy) will come to us for a share of our substance. And say that he (boy) does, and say that we give it him (boy), it isn't yourn we part from, and mayhap never will be.'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

On these occasions Gerard smiled slily, and picked up heart, and temporary confusion fell on Catherine's unfortunate allies. But at last, after more than six months of irritation, came the climax. The father told the son before the whole family he (father) had ordered the burgomaster to imprison him (father) in the Stadthouse rather than let him (father) marry Margaret. Gerard turned pale with anger at this, but by a great effort held his (Gerard) peace. His (Gerard) father went on to say,

``And a priest you shall be before the year is out, nilly-willy.'' (father)

``Then, hear me, all. By God and St. Bavon I swear I will never be a priest while Margaret lives. Since force is to decide it, and not love and duty, try force, father; but force shall not serve you, for the day I see the burgomaster come for me, I leave Tergou for ever, and Holland too, and my father's house, where it seems I have been valued all these years, not for myself, but for what is to be got out of me.'' (he)

And he (Gerard) flung out of the room white with anger and desperation.

``There!'' (Catherine)

Poor Gerard was overjoyed to be permitted to praise Margaret aloud, and to one who could understand what he (Gerard) loved in her (Margaret).

Soon there were two pair of wet eyes over his (Gerard) story; and when the poor boy saw that, there were three.

Women are creatures brimful of courage. Theirs is not exactly the same quality as manly courage; that would never do, hang it all; we should have to give up trampling on them. No; it is a vicarious courage. They never take part in a bull-fight by any chance; but it is remarked that they sit at one unshaken by those tremors and apprehensions for the combatants to which the male spectator--feeble-minded wretch!--is subject. Nothing can exceed the resolution with which they have been known to send forth men to battle: as some witty dog says,

``Les femmes sont tres braves avec le peur d’autrui.'' (some dog)

By this trait Gerard now profited. Margaret and Reicht were agreed that a man should always take the bull by the horns. Gerard's only course was to marry Margaret Brandt off-hand; the old people would come to after a while, the deed once done. Whereas, the longer this misunderstanding continued on its present footing, the worse for all parties, especially for Gerard.

``See how pale and thin they have made him (Les) amongst them.'' (unknown)

``Indeed you are, Master Gerard,'' (Reicht/Reicht Heynes)

``And I'll be bound the others keep their colour; ah, Reicht? such as it is.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I see no odds in them.'' (unknown)

``Of course not. We painters are no match for boors. We are glass, they are stone. We can't stand the worry, worry, worry of little minds; and it is not for the good of mankind we should be exposed to it. Exasperated as Gerard was by his (Gerard) father's threat of violence, he (Gerard) listened to these friendly voices telling him (Gerard) the prudent course was rebellion. But though he (Gerard) listened, he (Gerard) was not convinced.

I sometimes think if I could marry her (Margaret) secretly, and then take her (Margaret) away to some country where my craft is better paid than in this; and after a year or two, when the storm had blown over, you know, could come back with money in my purse, and say, `My dear parents, we do not seek your substance, we but ask you to love us once more as you used, and as we have never ceased to love you'--but, alas! I shall be told these are the dreams of an inexperienced young man.'' (he)

The old lady's eyes sparkled.

``It is no dream, but a piece of wonderful common-sense in a boy; it remains to be seen whether you have spirit to carry out your own thought. There is a country, Gerard, where certain fortune awaits you at this moment. Here the arts freeze, but there they flourish, as they never yet flourished in any age or land.'' (unknown)

``It is Italy!'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

(unknown)

``Find you the heart to go, I'll find the means. I know where to lay my hand on ten golden angels: they will take you to Rome: and the girl with you, if she (girl) loves you as she (girl) ought.'' (unknown)

They sat till midnight over this theme. And, after that day, Gerard recovered his (Gerard) spirits, and seemed to carry a secret talisman against all the gibes and the harsh words that flew about his (Gerard) ears at home.

Besides the money she (lady) procured him (Gerard) for the journey, Margaret Van Eyck gave him (Gerard) money's worth. Said she (Eyck),

``I will tell you secrets that I learned from masters that are gone from me, and have left no fellow behind. Even the Italians know them not; and what I tell you now in Tergou you shall sell here in Florence. Note my brother Jan's pictures: time, which fades all other paintings, leaves his (Jan) colours bright as the day they left the easel. The reason is, he (Jan) did nothing blindly, in a hurry. He (Jan) trusted to no hireling to grind his (Jan) colours; he (Jan) did it himself, or saw it done. His (Jan) panel was prepared and prepared again--I will show you how--a year before he (Jan) laid his (Jan) colour on. Most of them are quite content to have their work sucked up and lost, sooner than not be in a hurry. Bad painters are always in a hurry. Above all, Gerard, I warn you use but little oil, and never boil it: boiling it melts that vegetable dross into its heart which it is our business to clear away; for impure oil is death to colour. No; take your oil and pour it into a bottle with water. In a day or two the water will turn muddy: that is muck from the oil. Pour the dirty water carefully away and add fresh. When that is poured away, you will fancy the oil is clear. You're mistaken. Reicht, fetch me that!'' (she)
Reicht brought a glass trough with a glass lid fitting tight.
``When your oil has been washed in bottle, put it into this trough with water, and put the trough in the sun all day. You will soon see the water turbid again. But mark, you must not carry this game too far, or the sun will turn your oil to varnish. When it is as clear as crystal, not too luscious, drain carefully, and cork it up tight. Grind your own prime colours, and lay them on with this oil, and they shall live. Hubert would put sand or salt in the water to clear the oil quicker. But Jan used to say, `Water will do it best; give water time.' Jan Van Eyck was never in a hurry, and that is why the world will not forget him (Eyck) in a hurry.'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)

Thus provided with money and knowledge, Gerard decided to marry and fly with his (Gerard) wife to Italy. Nothing remained now but to inform Margaret Brandt of his (Gerard) resolution, and to publish the banns as quietly as possible. He (Gerard) went to Sevenbergen earlier than usual on both these errands. He (Gerard) began with Margaret; told her (Margaret) of the Dame Van Eyck's goodness, and the resolution he (Gerard) had come to at last, and invited her (Margaret) co-operation.

She (Margaret) refused it plump.

When a man misbehaves, the effect is curious on a girl who loves him (man) sincerely. It makes her (Margaret) pity him (man). This, to some of us males, seems anything but logical. The fault is in our own eye; the logic is too swift for us. The girl argues thus:--

``How unhappy, how vexed, how poor he (lover) must be to misbehave! Poor thing!'' (The girl)

Margaret was full of this sweet womanly pity, when, to her (Margaret) great surprise, scarce an hour and a half after he (man) left her (Margaret), Gerard came running back to her (Margaret) with the fragments of a picture in his (Gerard) hand, and panting with anger and grief.

``Who did it?'' (unknown)

CHAPTER X

The banns of marriage had to be read three times, as in our days; with this difference, that they were commonly read on week-days, and the young couple easily persuaded the cure to do the three readings in twenty-four hours: he (Martin) was new to the place, and their looks spoke volumes in their favour. They were cried on Monday at matins and at vespers; and, to their great delight, nobody from Tergou was in the church. The next morning they were both there, palpitating with anxiety, when, to their horror, a stranger stood up and forbade the banns, On the score that the parties were not of age, and their parents not consenting.

Outside the church door Margaret and Gerard held a trembling, and almost despairing consultation; but, before they could settle anything, the man who had done them so ill a turn approached, and gave them to understand that he (man) was very sorry to interfere: that his (man) inclination was to further the happiness of the young; but that in point of fact his (man) only means of getting a living was by forbidding banns: what then?

``The young people give me a crown, and I undo my work handsomely; tell the cure I was misinformed, and all goes smoothly.'' (unknown)

``A crown! I will give you a golden angel to do this,'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)
said Gerard eagerly; the man consented as eagerly, and went with Gerard to the cure, and told him (Gerard) he (Gerard) had made a ridiculous mistake, which a sight of the parties had rectified. On this the cure agreed to marry the young couple next day at ten: and the professional obstructor of bliss went home with Gerard's angel. Like most of these very clever knaves, he (Gerard) was a fool, and proceeded to drink his (Gerard) angel at a certain hostelry in Tergou where was a green devoted to archery and the common sports of the day. There, being drunk, he (Gerard) bragged of his (Gerard) day's exploit; and who should be there, imbibing every word, but a great frequenter of the spot, the ne’er-do-weel Sybrandt. Sybrandt ran home to tell his (Gerard) father; his (Gerard) father was not at home; he (Gerard) was gone to Rotterdam to buy cloth of the merchants. Catching his (Gerard) elder brother's eye, he (Gerard) made him (Gerard) a signal to come out, and told him (Gerard) what he (Gerard) had heard.

There are black sheep in nearly every large family; and these two were Gerard's black brothers. Idleness is vitiating: waiting for the death of those we ought to love is vitiating; and these two one-idea'd curs were ready to tear any one to death that should interfere with that miserable inheritance which was their thought by day and their dream by night. Their parents' parsimony was a virtue; it was accompanied by industry, and its motive was love of their offspring; but in these perverse and selfish hearts that homely virtue was perverted into avarice, than which no more fruitful source of crimes is to be found in nature.

They put their heads together, and agreed not to tell their mother, whose sentiments were so uncertain, but to go first to the burgomaster. They were cunning enough to see that he (mother) was averse to the match, though they could not divine why.

Ghysbrecht Van Swieten saw through them at once; but he (Swieten) took care not to let them see through him (Swieten). He (Swieten) heard their story, and putting on magisterial dignity and coldness, he (Swieten) said;

``Since the father of the family is not here, his (father) duty falleth on me, who am the father of the town. I know your father's mind; leave all to me; and, above all, tell not a woman a word of this, least of all the women that are in your own house: for chattering tongues mar wisest counsels.'' (he)

So he (Swieten) dismissed them, a little superciliously: he (Swieten) was ashamed of his (Swieten) confederates.

On their return home they found their brother Gerard seated on a low stool at their mother's knee: she (mother) was caressing his (Gerard) hair with her (mother) hand, speaking very kindly to him (Gerard), and promising to take his (Gerard) part with his (Gerard) father and thwart his (Gerard) love no more. The main cause of this change of mind was characteristic of the woman. She (woman) it was who in a moment of female irritation had cut Margaret's picture to pieces. She (Margaret) had watched the effect with some misgivings, and had seen Gerard turn pale as death, and sit motionless like a bereaved creature, with the pieces in his (Gerard) hands, and his (Gerard) eyes fixed on them till tears came and blinded them. Then she (Margaret) was terrified at what she (Margaret) had done; and next her (Margaret) heart smote her (Margaret) bitterly; and she (Margaret) wept sore apart; but, being what she (Margaret) was, dared not own it, but said to herself,

``I'll not say a word, but I'll make it up to him (father).'' (she)
And her (Margaret) bowels yearned over her (Margaret) son, and her (Margaret) feeble violence died a natural death, and she (Margaret) was transferring her (Margaret) fatal alliance to Gerard when the two black sheep came in. Gerard knew nothing of the immediate cause; on the contrary, inexperienced as he (Gerard) was in the ins and outs of females, her (Margaret) kindness made him (Gerard) ashamed of a suspicion he (Gerard) had entertained that she (Margaret) was the depredator, and he (Gerard) kissed her (Margaret) again and again, and went to bed happy as a prince to think his (prince) mother was his (prince) mother once more at the very crisis of his (prince) fate.

The next morning, at ten o’clock, Gerard and Margaret were in the church at Sevenbergen, he (Gerard) radiant with joy, she (Margaret) with blushes. Peter was also there, and Martin Wittenhaagen, but no other friend. Secrecy was everything. Margaret had declined Italy. She (Margaret) could not leave her (Margaret) father; he (father) was too learned and too helpless. But it was settled they should retire into Flanders for a few weeks until the storm should be blown over at Tergou. The cure did not keep them waiting long, though it seemed an age. Presently he (Flanders) stood at the altar, and called them to him (Flanders). They went hand in hand, the happiest in Holland. The cure opened his (Flanders) book.

But ere he (Flanders) uttered a single word of the sacred rite, a harsh voice cried

``Forbear!'' (he)
And the constables of Tergou came up the aisle and seized Gerard in the name of the law. Martin's long knife flashed out directly.

``Forbear, man!'' (the priest)
cried the priest.
``What! draw your weapon in a church, and ye who interrupt this holy sacrament, what means this impiety?'' (unknown)

``There is no impiety, father,'' (the burgomaster)
said the burgomaster's servant respectfully.
``This young man would marry against his (man) father's will, and his (man) father has prayed our burgomaster to deal with him (man) according to the law. Let him (man) deny it if he (man) can.'' (unknown)

``Is this so, young man?'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

Gerard hung his (Gerard) head.

``We take him (man) to Rotterdam to abide the sentence of the Duke.'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)

At this Margaret uttered a cry of despair, and the young creatures, who were so happy a moment ago, fell to sobbing in one another's arms so piteously, that the instruments of oppression drew back a step and were ashamed; but one of them that was good-natured stepped up under pretence of separating them, and whispered to Margaret:

``Rotterdam? it is a lie. We but take him (man) to our Stadthouse.'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)

They took him (Gerard) away on horseback, on the road to Rotterdam; and, after a dozen halts, and by sly detours, to Tergou. Just outside the town they were met by a rude vehicle covered with canvas. Gerard was put into this, and about five in the evening was secretly conveyed into the prison of the Stadthouse. He (Gerard) was taken up several flights of stairs and thrust into a small room lighted only by a narrow window, with a vertical iron bar. The whole furniture was a huge oak chest.

Imprisonment in that age was one of the highroads to death. It is horrible in its mildest form; but in those days it implied cold, unbroken solitude, torture, starvation, and often poison. Gerard felt he (Gerard) was in the hands of an enemy.

``Oh, the look that man gave me on the road to Rotterdam. There is more here than my father's wrath. I doubt I shall see no more the light of day.'' (he)
And he (Gerard) kneeled down and commended his (Gerard) soul to God.

Presently he (Gerard) rose and sprang at the iron bar of the window, and clutched it. This enabled him (Gerard) to look out by pressing his (Gerard) knees against the wall. It was but for a minute; but in that minute he (Gerard) saw a sight such as none but a captive can appreciate.

Martin Wittenhaagen's back.

Martin was sitting, quietly fishing in the brook near the Stadthouse.

Gerard sprang again at the window, and whistled. Martin instantly showed that he (Martin) was watching much harder than fishing. He (Martin) turned hastily round and saw Gerard--made him (Gerard) a signal, and taking up his (Gerard) line and bow, went quickly off.

Gerard saw by this that his (Gerard) friends were not idle: yet had rather Martin had stayed. The very sight of him (Martin) was a comfort. He (Martin) held on, looking at the soldier's retiring form as long as he (Martin) could, then falling back somewhat heavily wrenched the rusty iron bar, held only by rusty nails, away from the stone-work just as Ghysbrecht Van Swieten opened the door stealthily behind him (Swieten). The burgomaster's eye fell instantly on the iron, and then glanced at the window; but he (Swieten) said nothing. The window was a hundred feet from the ground; and if Gerard had a fancy for jumping out, why should he (Gerard) balk it? He (Gerard) brought a brown loaf and a pitcher of water, and set them on the chest in solemn silence. Gerard's first impulse was to brain him (Gerard) with the iron bar and fly down the stairs; but the burgomaster seeing something wicked in his (Gerard) eye, gave a little cough, and three stout fellows, armed, showed themselves directly at the door.

``My orders are to keep you thus until you shall bind yourself by an oath to leave Margaret Brandt, and return to the Church, to which you have belonged from your cradle.'' (unknown)

``Death sooner.'' (unknown)

``With all my heart.'' (the burgomaster)
And the burgomaster retired.

Martin went with all speed to Sevenbergen; there he (Martin) found Margaret pale and agitated, but full of resolution and energy. She (Margaret) was just finishing a letter to the Countess Charolois, appealing to her (Countess) against the violence and treachery of Ghysbrecht.

``Courage!'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
cried Martin on entering.
``I have found him (father). He (father) is in the haunted tower, right at the top of it. Ay, I know the place: many a poor fellow has gone up there straight, and come down feet foremost.'' (He)

He (Martin) then told them how he (Martin) had looked up and seen Gerard's face at a window that was like a slit in the wall.

``Oh, Martin! how did he (Martin) look?'' (unknown)

``What mean you? He (Martin) looked like Gerard Eliassoen.'' (unknown)

The first day of imprisonment is very trying, especially if to the horror of captivity is added the horror of utter solitude. I observe that in our own day a great many persons commit suicide during the first twenty-four hours of the solitary cell. Such as can retain their senses after the first prostrating effect of the supernatural are apt to experience terror in one of its strangest forms, a wild desire to fling themselves upon the terrible object. It fascinates them as the snake the bird. The great tragedian Macready used to render this finely in Macbeth, at Banquo's second appearance. He (Macbeth) flung himself with averted head at the horrible shadow. This strange impulse now seized Margaret. She (Margaret) put down Gerard's hand quietly, and stood bewildered; then, all in a moment, with a wild cry, darted towards the spectre. Affection sharpens the wits, and often it has made an innocent person more than a match for the wily. CHAPTER XIII

Gerard and Margaret went gaily to Sevenbergen in the first flush of recovered liberty and successful adventure. But these soon yielded to sadder thoughts. Gerard was an escaped prisoner, and liable to be retaken and perhaps punished; and therefore he (Gerard) and Margaret would have to part for a time. Moreover, he (Gerard) had conceived a hatred to his (Gerard) native place. Margaret wished him (Gerard) to leave the country for a while, but at the thought of his (Gerard) going to Italy her (Margaret) heart fainted. Gerard, on the contrary, was reconciled to leaving Margaret only by his (Gerard) desire to visit Italy, and his (Gerard) strong conviction that there he (Gerard) should earn money and reputation, and remove every obstacle to their marriage. He (Gerard) had already told her (Margaret) all that the demoiselle Van Eyck had said to him (Gerard). He (Gerard) repeated it, and reminded Margaret that the gold pieces were only given him (Gerard) to go to Italy with. The journey was clearly for Gerard's interest. He (Gerard) was a craftsman and an artist, lost in this boorish place. In Italy they would know how to value him (Gerard). On this ground above all the unselfish girl gave her (girl) consent; but many tender tears came with it, and at that Gerard, young and loving as herself, cried bitterly with her (girl), and often they asked one another what they had done, that so many different persons should be their enemies, and combine, as it seemed, to part them.

They sat hand in hand till midnight, now deploring their hard fate, now drawing bright and hopeful pictures of the future, in the midst of which Margaret's tears would suddenly flow, and then poor Gerard's eloquence would die away in a sigh.

The morning found them resigned to part, but neither had the courage to say when; and much I doubt whether the hour of parting ever would have struck.

But about three in the afternoon, Giles, who had made a circuit of many miles to avoid suspicion, rode up to the door. They both ran out to him (Giles), eager with curiosity.

``Brother Gerard,'' (he)
cried he (Giles), in his (Giles) tremendous tones,
``Kate bids you run for your life. They charge you with theft; you have given them a handle. Think not to explain. Hope not for justice in Tergou. The parchments you took, they are but a blind. She (Kate) hath seen your death in the men's eyes; a price is on your head. Fly! For Margaret's sake and all who love you, loiter not life away, but fly!'' (he)

It was a thunder-clap, and left two white faces looking at one another, and at the terrible messenger.

Then Giles, who had hitherto but uttered by rote what Catherine bade him (Giles), put in a word of his (Giles) own.

``All the constables were at our house after you, and so was Dirk Brower. Kate is wise, Gerard. Best give ear to her (Kate) rede, and fly!'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, Gerard,'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)

``For I shall be gone ere you reach home,'' (he)

Surprise thus provided against, Gerard breathed again. He (Gerard) went with Margaret, and while she (Margaret) watched the oak-tree tremblingly, fearing every moment to see an arrow strike among the branches, Gerard dug a deep hole to bury the parchments in.

``The road is clear,'' (he)

His (Martin) words proved true. The thunder came nearer and nearer till it crashed overhead: the flashes followed one another close, like the strokes of a whip, and the rain fell in torrents. The lovers consulted together, and Gerard blessed the storm that gave him (Gerard) a few hours more with Margaret. The sun set unperceived, and still the thunder pealed, and the lightning flashed, and the rain poured. Supper was set; but Gerard and Margaret could not eat: the thought that this was the last time they should sup together choked them. The storm lulled a little. Peter retired to rest. But Gerard was to go at peep of day, and neither he (Gerard) nor Margaret could afford to lose an hour in sleep. Martin sat a while, too; for he (Martin) was fitting a new string to his (Martin) bow, a matter in which he (Martin) was very nice.

The lovers murmured their sorrows and their love beside him (Martin).

They were quiet and listened, and heard nothing. But the next moment a footstep crackled faintly upon the autumn leaves that lay strewn in the garden at the back door of the house. To those who had nothing to fear such a step would have said nothing; but to those who had enemies it was terrible. For it was a foot trying to be noiseless.

Martin fitted an arrow to his (Martin) string and hastily blew out the candle. At this moment, to their horror, they heard more than one footstep approach the other door of the cottage, not quite so noiselessly as the other, but very stealthily--and then a dead pause.

Their blood froze in their veins.

``Oh, Kate, oh, Kate! You said fly on the instant.'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)

A heavy knock fell on the door.

And on the hearts within.

CHAPTER XIV

As if this had been a concerted signal, the back door was struck as rudely the next instant. They were hemmed in. But at these alarming sounds Margaret seemed to recover some share of self-possession. She (Margaret) whispered,

``Say he (Gerard) was here, but is gone.'' (She)

A wet jerkin apiece, that is all we shall get, mates, by this job.'' (Dierich/Dierich Brower/Brower)

Martin grinned coolly in Dierich's face.

``However,'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
added the latter,
``to content the burgomaster, we will search the house.'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)

Martin turned grave directly.

This change of countenance did not escape Dierich. He (Dierich) reflected a moment.

``Watch outside two of you, one on each side of the house, that no one jump from the upper windows. The rest come with me.'' (he)

And he (Dierich) took the candle and mounted the stairs, followed by three of his (Dierich) comrades.

Martin was left alone.

The stout soldier hung his (Martin) head. All had gone so well at first; and now this fatal turn! Suddenly it occurred to him (Martin) that all was not yet lost. Gerard must be either in Peter's room or Margaret's; they were not so very high from the ground. Gerard would leap out. Dierich had left a man below; but what then? For half a minute Gerard and he (Gerard) would be two to one, and in that brief space, what might not be done?

Martin then held the back door ajar and watched. The light shone in Peter's room.

``Curse the fool!'' (he)
said he (Peter),
``is he (fool) going to let them take him (fool) like a girl?'' (he)

He (Martin) began to think Gerard must have escaped by the window while all the men were in the house. The longer the silence continued, the stronger grew this conviction. But it was suddenly and rudely dissipated.

Faint cries issued from the inner bedroom--Margaret's.

``They have taken him (fool),'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)
groaned Martin;
``they have got him (fool).'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)

He (Gerard) cast his (Gerard) eyes wildly round like some savage beast seeking an escape, and in a twinkling formed a resolution terribly characteristic of those iron times and of a soldier driven to bay. He (soldier) stepped to each door in turn, and imitating Dierich Brower's voice, said sharply,

``Watch the window!'' (Dierich/Dierich Brower/Brower)
He (Brower) then quietly closed and bolted both doors. He (Brower) then took up his (Brower) bow and six arrows; one he (Brower) fitted to his (Brower) string, the others he (Brower) put into his (Brower) quiver. Two, he (Brower) knew, he (Brower) could dispose of by his (Brower) arrows, ere they could get near him (Brower), and Gerard and he (Gerard) must take their chance hand-to-hand with the remaining pair. Besides, he (Gerard) had seen men panic-stricken by a sudden attack of this sort. Should Brower and his (Brower) men hesitate but an instant before closing with him (Brower), he (Brower) should shoot three instead of two, and then the odds would be on the right side.

He (Brower) had not long to wait. The heavy steps sounded in Margaret's room, and came nearer and nearer.

The light also approached, and voices.

Martin's heart, stout as it was, beat hard, to hear men coming thus to their death, and perhaps to his (Martin); more likely so than not: for four is long odds in a battlefield of ten feet square, and Gerard might be bound perhaps, and powerless to help. But this man, whom we have seen shake in his (man) shoes at a Giles-o'-lanthorn, never wavered in this awful moment of real danger, but stood there, his (man) body all braced for combat, and his (man) eye glowing, equally ready to take life and lose it. Desperate game! to win which was exile instant and for life, and to lose it was to die that moment upon that floor he (man) stood on.

Dierich Brower and his (Brower) men found Peter in his (Brower) first sleep. They opened his (Brower) cupboards, they ran their knives into an alligator he (Brower) had nailed to his (Brower) wall; they looked under his (Brower) bed: it was a large room, and apparently full of hiding-places, but they found no Gerard.

Then they went on to Margaret's room, and the very sight of it was discouraging--it was small and bare, and not a cupboard in it; there was, however, a large fireplace and chimney. Dierich's eye fell on these directly. Here they found the beauty of Sevenbergen sleeping on an old chest not a foot high, and no attempt made to cover it; but the sheets were snowy white, and so was Margaret's own linen. And there she (Margaret) lay, looking like a lily fallen into a rut.

Presently she (Margaret) awoke, and sat up in the bed, like one amazed; then, seeing the men, began to scream faintly, and pray for mercy.

She (Margaret) made Dierich Brower ashamed of his (Brower) errand.

``Here is a to-do,'' (he)
said he (Brower), a little confused.
``We are not going to hurt you, my pretty maid. Lie you still, and shut your eyes, and think of your wedding-night, while I look up this chimney to see if Master Gerard is there.'' (unknown)

``Gerard! in my room?'' (unknown)

``Why not? They say that you and he (Gerard)--'' (unknown)

You are thieves; you are wicked men; you are not men of Sevenbergen, or you would know Margaret Brandt better than to look for her (men) lover in this room of all others in the world. Oh, brave! ``There! come away, before we hear worse,'' (Dierich/Dierich Brower/Brower)

``He (character) is not in the chimney. Plaster will mend what a cudgel breaks; but a woman's tongue is a double-edged dagger, and a girl is a woman with her (girl) mother's milk still in her (girl).'' (he)
And he (Dierich) beat a hasty retreat.
``I told the burgomaster how `twould be.'' (CHAPTER XV)

CHAPTER XV

Where is the woman that cannot act a part? Where is she (woman) who will not do it, and do it well, to save the man she (woman) loves? Nature on these great occasions comes to the aid of the simplest of the sex, and teaches her (woman) to throw dust in Solomon's eyes. The men had no sooner retired than Margaret stepped out of bed, and opened the long chest on which she (Margaret) had been lying down in her (Margaret) skirt and petticoat and stockings, and nightdress over all; and put the lid, bed-clothes and all, against the wall: then glided to the door and listened. The footsteps died away through her (Margaret) father's room and down the stairs.

Now in that chest there was a peculiarity that it was almost impossible for a stranger to detect. A part of the boarding of the room had been broken, and Gerard being applied to to make it look neater, and being short of materials, had ingeniously sawed away a space sufficient just to admit Margaret's soi-disant bed, and with the materials thus acquired he (Gerard) had repaired the whole room. As for the bed or chest, it really rested on the rafters a foot below the boards. Consequently it was full two feet deep, though it looked scarce one.

All was quiet. Margaret kneeled and gave thanks to Heaven. Then she (Margaret) glided from the door and leaned over the chest, and whispered tenderly,

``Gerard!'' (she)

Gerard did not reply.

She (Margaret) then whispered a little louder,

``Gerard, all is safe, thank Heaven! You may rise; but oh! be cautious!'' (She)

Gerard made no reply.

She (Margaret) laid her (Margaret) hand upon his (Gerard) shoulder--

``Gerard!'' (She)

No reply.

``Oh, what is this?'' (she)
she (Margaret) cried, and her (Margaret) hands ran wildly over his (Gerard) face and his (Gerard) bosom. She (Margaret) took him (Gerard) by the shoulders; she (Margaret) shook him (Gerard); she (Margaret) lifted him (Gerard); but he (Gerard) escaped from her (Margaret) trembling hands, and fell back, not like a man, but like a body. A great dread fell on her (Margaret). The lid had been down. She (Margaret) had lain upon it. The men had been some time in the room. With all the strength of frenzy she (Margaret) tore him (man) out of the chest. She (Margaret) bore him (man) in her (Margaret) arms to the window. She (Margaret) dashed the window open. The sweet air came in. She (Margaret) laid him (man) in it and in the moonlight. His (man) face was the colour of ashes; his (man) body was all limp and motionless. She (Margaret) felt his (man) heart. Horror! it was as still as the rest! Horror of horrors! she (Margaret) had stifled him (man) with her (Margaret) own body.

The mind cannot all at once believe so great and sudden and strange a calamity. Gerard, who had got alive into that chest scarce five minutes ago, how could he (Gerard) be dead?

She (Margaret) called him (Gerard) by all the endearing names that heart could think or tongue could frame. She (Margaret) kissed him (Gerard) and fondled him (Gerard) and coaxed him (Gerard) and implored him (Gerard) to speak to her (Margaret).

No answer to words of love, such as she (Margaret) had never uttered to him (Gerard) before, nor thought she (Margaret) could utter. Then the poor creature, trembling all over, began to say over that ashy face little foolish things that were at once terrible and pitiable.

``Oh, Gerard! I am very sorry you are dead. I am very sorry I have killed you. Forgive me for not letting the men take you; it would have been better than this. Oh, Gerard! I am very, very sorry for what I have done.'' (she)
Then she (Margaret) began suddenly to rave.

``No! no! such things can't be, or there is no God. It is monstrous. How can my Gerard be dead? How can I have killed my Gerard? I love him (Gerard). Oh, God! you know how I love him (Gerard). Thus Gerard, in one terrible night, grazed the prison and the grave.

And how did he (Gerard) get clear at last? Not by his (Gerard) cunningly contrived hiding-place, nor by Margaret's ready wit; but by a good impulse in one of his (Gerard) captors, by the bit of humanity left in a somewhat reckless fellow's heart, aided by his (Gerard) desire of gain. So mixed and seemingly incongruous are human motives, so shortsighted our shrewdest counsels.

They whose moderate natures or gentle fates keep them, in life's passage, from the fierce extremes of joy and anguish our nature is capable of, are perhaps the best, and certainly the happiest of mankind. But to such readers I should try in vain to convey what bliss unspeakable settled now upon these persecuted lovers, Even to those who have joyed greatly and greatly suffered, my feeble art can present but a pale reflection of Margaret's and Gerard's ecstasy.

To sit and see a beloved face come back from the grave to the world, to health and beauty, by swift gradations; to see the roses return to the loved cheek, love's glance to the loved eye, and his (Gerard) words to the loved mouth--this was Margaret's--a joy to balance years of sorrow. It was Gerard's to awake from a trance, and find his (Gerard) head pillowed on Margaret's arm; to hear the woman he (Gerard) adored murmur new words of eloquent love, and shower tears and tender kisses and caresses on him (Gerard). He (Gerard) never knew, till this sweet moment, how ardently, how tenderly, she (woman) loved him (Gerard). He (Gerard) thanked his (Gerard) enemies. They wreathed their arms sweetly round each other, and trouble and danger seemed a world, an age behind them. They called each other husband and wife. Were they not solemnly betrothed? And had they not stood before the altar together? Was not the blessing of Holy Church upon their union?--her (wife) curse on all who would part them?

But as no woman's nerves can bear with impunity so terrible a strain. presently Margaret turned faint, and sank on Gerard's shoulder, smiling feebly, but quite, quite unstrung. Then Gerard was anxious, and would seek assistance. But she (Margaret) held him (Gerard) with a gentle grasp, and implored him (Gerard) not to leave her (Margaret) for a moment.

``While I can lay my hand on you, I feel you are safe, not else. Foolish Gerard! nothing ails me. I am weak, dearest, but happy, oh! so happy!'' (Gerard/Ser Gerard/Ser)

Then it was Gerard's turn to support that dear head, with its great waves of hair flowing loose over him (Gerard), and nurse her (nurse), and soothe her (nurse), quivering on his (Gerard) bosom, with soft encouraging words and murmurs of love, and gentle caresses. Sweetest of all her (nurse) charms is a woman's weakness to a manly heart.

Poor things! they were happy. To-morrow they must part. But that was nothing to them now. They had seen Death, and all other troubles seemed light as air. While there is life there is hope; while there is hope there is joy. Separation for a year or two, what was it to them, who were so young, and had caught a glimpse of the grave? The future was bright, the present was Heaven: so passed the blissful hours.

Alas! their innocence ran other risks besides the prison and the grave. They were in most danger from their own hearts and their inexperience, now that visible danger there was none.

CHAPTER XIX

Peter's house was but a furlong and a half from the forest. They started, Martin with his (Martin) bow and three arrows, for it was Thursday; Gerard with nothing but a stout oak staff Peter gave him (Peter) for the journey.

CHAPTER XX

The courage, like the talent, of common men, runs in a narrow groove. Take them but an inch out of that, and they are done. Martin's courage was perfect as far as it went. He (Martin) had met and baffled many dangers in the course of his (Martin) rude life, and these familiar dangers he (Martin) could face with Spartan fortitude, almost with indifference; but he (Martin) had never been hunted by a bloodhound, nor had he (Martin) ever seen that brute's unerring instinct baffled by human cunning. Here then a sense of the supernatural combined with novelty to ungenteel his (Martin) heart. After going a few steps, he (Martin) leaned on his (Martin) bow, and energy and hope oozed out of him (Martin). Gerard, to whom the danger appeared slight in proportion as it was distant, urged him (Gerard) to flight.

``What avails it?'' (Martin/Martin Wittenhaagen)

Strange that things beautiful should be terrible and deadly' The eye of the boa-constrictor, while fascinating its prey, is lovely.
