CHAPTER LXXX

THE CLOISTER

Brother Clement had taught and preached in Basle more than a twelvemonth, when one day Jerome stood before him (Jerome), dusty, with a triumphant glance in his (Jerome) eye.

``Give the glory to God, Brother Clement; thou canst now wend to England with me.'' (unknown)

``I am ready, Brother Jerome; and expecting thee these many months, have in the intervals of teaching and devotion studied the English tongue somewhat closely.'' (unknown)

```Twas well thought of,'' said Jerome. He (Jerome) then told him (Jerome) he (Jerome) had but delayed till he (Jerome) could obtain extraordinary powers from the Pope to collect money for the Church's use in England, and to hear confession in all the secular monasteries.

``So now gird up thy loins, and let us go forth and deal a good blow for the Church, and against the Franciscans.'' (The friars)

The two friars went preaching down the Rhine for England. In the larger places they both preached. At the smaller they often divided, and took different sides of the river, and met again at some appointed spot. Both were able orators, but in different styles.

Jerome's was noble and impressive, but a little contracted in religious topics, and a trifle monotonous in delivery compared with Clement's, though in truth not so, compared with most preachers.

Clement's was full of variety, and often remarkably colloquial. In its general flow, tender and gently winning, it curled round the reason and the heart. But it always rose with the rising thought; and so at times Clement soared as far above Jerome as his (Clement) level speaking was below him (Clement). Indeed, in these noble heats he (Clement) was all that we hue read of inspired prophet or heathen orator: Vehemens ut procella, excitatus ut torrens, incensus ut fulmen, tonabat, fulgurabat, et rapidis eloquentiae fiuctibus cuncta proruebat et perturbabat.

I would give literal specimens, but for five objections; it is difficult; time is short; I have done it elsewhere; an able imitator has since done it better and similarity, a virtue in peas, is a vice in books.

But -LRB-not to evade the matter entirely-RRB- Clement used secretly to try and learn the recent events and the besetting sin of each town he (Clement) was to preach in.

But Jerome, the unbending, scorned to go out of his (Jerome) way for any people's vices. At one great town, some leagues from the Rhine, they mounted the same pulpit in turn. Jerome preached against vanity in dress, a favourite theme of his (Jerome). He (Jerome) was eloquent and satirical, and the people listened with complacency. It was a vice that they were little given to.

Clement preached against drunkenness. It was a besetting sin, and sacred from preaching in these parts: for the clergy themselves were infected with it, and popular prejudice protected it, Clement dealt it merciless blows out of Holy Writ and worldly experience. A crime itself, it was the nursing mother of most crimes, especially theft and murder. He (Clement) reminded them of a parricide that had lately been committed in their town by all honest man in liquor; and also how a band of drunkards had roasted one of their own comrades alive at a neighbouring village.

``Your last prince,'' (he)
said he (man),
``is reported to have died of apoplexy, but well you know he (prince) died of drink; and of your aldermen one perished miserably last month dead drunk, suffocated in a puddle. Your children's backs go bare that you may fill your bellies with that which makes you the worst of beasts, silly as calves, yet fierce as boars; and drives your families to need, and your souls to hell. I tell ye your town, ay, and your very nation, would sink to the bottom of mankind did your women drink as you do. And how long will they be temperate, and contrary to nature, resist the example of their husbands and fathers? Vice ne’er yet stood still. Ye must amend yourselves, or see them come down to your mark, Already in Bohemia they drink along with the men. How shows a drunken woman? Would you love to see your wives drunken, your mothers drunken?'' (he)
At this there was a shout of horror, for mediaeval audiences had not learned to sit mumchance at a moving sermon.
``Ah, that comes home to you,'' (the friar)
cried the friar.
``What madmen! think you it doth not more shock the all-pure God to see a man, His (God) noblest work, turned to a drunken beast, than it can shock you creatures of sin and unreason to see a woman turned into a thing no better nor worse than yourselves.'' (He)

He (friar) ended with two pictures: a drunkard's house and family, and a sober man's; both so true and dramatic in all their details that the wives fell all to

``ohing'' (the wives)
and
``ahing,'' (the wives)
and
``Eh, but that is a true word.'' (the wives)

This discourse caused quite all uproar. The hearers formed knots; the men were indignant; so the women flattered them and took their part openly against the preacher. A married man had a right to a drop; he (man) needed it, working for all the family. And for their part they did not care to change their men for milksops.

The double faces! That very evening a hand of men caught near a hundred of them round Brother Clement, filling his (Clement) wallet with the best, and offering him (Clement) the very roses off their heads, and kissing his (Clement) frock, and blessing him (Clement)

``for taking in hand to mend their sots.'' (him)

Jerome thought this sermon too earthly.

``Drunkenness is not heresy, Clement, that a whole sermon should be preached against it.'' (he)

As they went on, he (Jerome) found to his (Jerome) surprise that Clement's sermons sank into his (Jerome) hearers deeper than his (Jerome) own; made them listen, think, cry, and sometimes even amend their ways.

``He (Clement) hath the art of sinking to their peg,'' (Jerome/St. Jerome)
thought Jerome,
``Yet he (Clement) can soar high enough at times.'' (Jerome/St. Jerome)

Upon the whole it puzzled Jerome, who had a secret sense of superiority to his (Jerome) tenderer brother. And after about two hundred miles of it, it got to displease him (Jerome) as well as puzzle him (Jerome). But he (Jerome) tried to check this sentiment as petty and unworthy.

``Souls differ like locks,'' (he)
said he (Jerome),
``and preachers must differ like keys, or the fewer should the Church open for God to pass in. And certes, this novice hath the key to these northern souls, being himself a northern man.'' (he)

And so they came slowly down the Rhine, sometimes drifting a few miles down the stream; but in general walking by the banks preaching, and teaching, and confessing sinners in the towns and villages; and they reached the town of Dusseldorf.

There was the little quay where Gerard and Denys had taken boat up the Rhine, The friars landed on it. There were the streets, there was

``The Silver Lion.'' (he)
Nothing had changed but he (Gerard), who walked through it barefoot, with his (Gerard) heart calm and cold, his (Gerard) hands across his (Gerard) breast, and his (Gerard) eyes bent meekly on the ground, a true son of Dominic and Holy Church.

THE CLOISTER

The two friars reached Holland from the south just twelve hours after Luke started up the Rhine.

Thus, wild-goose chase or not, the parties were nearing each other, and rapidly too. For Jerome, unable to preach in low Dutch, now began to push on towards the coast, anxious to get to England as soon as possible.

And having the stream with them, the friars would in point of fact have missed Luke by passing him (Luke) in full stream below his (Luke) station, but for the incident which I am about to relate.

THE HEARTH

And that letter was one of those simple, touching appeals only her (Margaret) sex can write to those who have used them cruelly, and they love them. She (Margaret) began by telling him (boy) of the birth of the little boy, and the comfort he (boy) had been to her (Margaret) in all the distress of mind his (boy) long and strange silence had caused her (Margaret). She (Margaret) described the little Gerard minutely, not forgetting the mole on his (Gerard) little finger.

``Know you any one that hath the like on his (sinner)? If you only saw him (sinner) you could not choose but be proud of him (sinner); all the mothers in the street do envy me; but I the wives; for thou comest not to us. My own Gerard, some say thou art dead. But if thou wert dead, how could I be alive? Others say that thou, whom I love so truly, art false. But this will I believe from no lips but thine. My father loved thee well; and as he (father) lay a-dying he (father) thought he (father) saw thee on a great river, with thy face turned towards thy Margaret, but sore disfigured. Is't so, perchance? Have cruel men scarred thy sweet face? or hast thou lost one of thy precious limbs? Why, then thou hast the more need of me, and I shall love thee not worse, alas! thinkest thou a woman's love is light as a man's? but better, than I did when I shed those few drops from my arm, not worth the tears, thou didst shed for them; mindest thou? `tis not so very long agone, dear Gerard.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER LXXXIV

CHAPTER LXXXV

THE CLOISTER AND THE HEARTH

The sermon had begun when Margaret entered the great church of St. Laurens. It was a huge edifice, far from completed. Churches were not built in a year. The side aisles were roofed, but not the mid aisle nor the chancel; the pillars and arches were pretty perfect, and some of them whitewashed. But only one window in the whole church was glazed; the rest were at present great jagged openings in the outer walls.

But to-day all these uncouth imperfections made the church beautiful. It was a glorious summer afternoon, and the sunshine came broken into marvellous forms through those irregular openings, and played bewitching pranks upon so many broken surfaces.

It streamed through the gaping walls, and clove the dark cool side aisles with rivers of glory, and dazzled and glowed on the white pillars beyond.

And nearly the whole central aisle was chequered with light and shade in broken outlines; the shades seeming cooler and more soothing than ever shade was, and the lights like patches of amber diamond animated with heavenly fire. And above, from west to east the blue sky vaulted the lofty aisle, and seemed quite close.

The sunny caps of the women made a sea of white contrasting exquisitely with that vivid vault of blue.

For the mid aisle, huge as it was, was crammed, yet quite still. The words and the mellow, gentle, earnest voice of the preacher held them mute.

Margaret stood spellbound at the beauty, the devotion,

``the great calm,'' (Margaret/Margaret Van Eyck/Van Eyck)
She (Margaret) got behind a pillar in the north aisle; and there, though she (Margaret) could hardly catch a word, a sweet devotional langour crept over her (Margaret) at the loveliness of the place and the preacher's musical voice; and balmy oil seemed to trickle over the waves in her (Margaret) heart and smooth them. So she (Margaret) leaned against the pillar with eyes half closed, and all seemed soft and dreamy.

She (Margaret) felt it good to be there.

Presently she (Margaret) saw a lady leave an excellent place opposite to get out of the sun, which was indeed pouring on her (Margaret) head from the window. Margaret went round softly but swiftly; and was fortunate enough to get the place. She (Margaret) was now beside a pillar of the south aisle, and not above fifty feet from the preacher. She (Margaret) was at his (preacher) side, a little behind him (preacher), but could hear every word.

Her (Margaret) attention, however, was soon distracted by the shadow of a man's head and shoulders bobbing up and down so drolly she (Margaret) had some ado to keep from smiling.

Yet it was nothing essentially droll.

It was the sexton digging.

She (Margaret) found that out in a moment by looking behind her (Margaret), through the window, to whence the shadow came.

Now as she (Margaret) was looking at Jorian Ketel digging, suddenly a tone of the preacher's voice fell upon her (Margaret) ear and her (Margaret) mind so distinctly, it seemed literally to strike her (Margaret), and make her (Margaret) vibrate inside and out.

Her (Margaret) hand went to her (Margaret) bosom, so strange and sudden was the thrill. Then she (Margaret) turned round, and looked at the preacher. His (preacher) back was turned, and nothing visible but his (preacher) tonsure. She (Margaret) sighed. That tonsure, being all she (Margaret) saw, contradicted the tone effectually.

Yet she (Margaret) now leaned a little forward with downcast eyes, hoping for that accent again. It did not come. But the whole voice grew strangely upon her (Margaret). It rose and fell as the preacher warmed; and it seemed to waken faint echoes of a thousand happy memories. She (Margaret) would not look to dispel the melancholy pleasure this voice gave her (Margaret).

Presently, in the middle of an eloquent period, the preacher stopped.

She (Margaret) almost sighed; a soothing music had ended. Could the sermon be ended already? No; she (Margaret) looked round; the people did not move.

A good many faces seemed now to turn her (Margaret) way.' She (Margaret) looked behind her (Margaret) sharply. There was nothing there.

Startled countenances near her (Margaret) now eyed the preacher. She (Margaret) followed their looks; and there, in the pulpit, was a face as of a staring corpse. The friar's eyes, naturally large, and made larger by the thinness of his (friar) cheeks, were dilated to supernatural size, and glaring her (Margaret) way out of a bloodless face.

She (Margaret) cringed and turned fearfully round: for she (Margaret) thought there must be some terrible thing near her (Margaret). No; there was nothing; she (Margaret) was the outside figure of the listening crowd.

At this moment the church fell into commotion, Figures got up all over the building, and craned forward; agitated faces by hundreds gazed from the friar to Margaret, and from Margaret to the friar. The turning to and fro of so many caps made a loud rustle. Then came shrieks of nervous women, and buzzing of men; and Margaret, seeing so many eyes levelled at her (Margaret), shrank terrified behind the pillar, with one scared, hurried glance at the preacher.

Momentary as that glance was, it caught in that stricken face an expression that made her (Margaret) shiver.

She (Margaret) turned faint, and sat down on a heap of chips the workmen had left, and buried her (Margaret) face in her (Margaret) hands, The sermon went on again. She (Margaret) heard the sound of it; but not the sense. She (Margaret) tried to think, but her (Margaret) mind was in a whirl, Thought would fix itself in no shape but this: that on that prodigy-stricken face she (Margaret) had seen a look stamped. And the recollection of that look now made her (Margaret) quiver from head to foot.

For that look was

``RECOGNITION.'' (the preacher)

The sermon, after wavering some time, ended in a strain of exalted, nay, feverish eloquence, that went far to make the crowd forget the preacher's strange pause and ghastly glare. Margaret mingled hastily with the crowd, and went out of the church with them.

They went their ways home. But she (Margaret) turned at the door, and went into the churchyard; to Peter's grave. Poor as she (Margaret) was, she (Margaret) had given him (Peter) a slab and a headstone. She (Margaret) sat down on the slab, and kissed it. Then threw her (Margaret) apron over her (Margaret) head that no one might distinguish her (Margaret) by her (Margaret) hair.

``Father,'' (she)
she (Margaret) said,
``thou hast often heard me say I am wading in deep waters; but now I begin to think God only knows the bottom of them. I'll follow that friar round the world, but I'll see him (friar) at arm's length. And he (friar) shall tell me why he (friar) looked towards me like a dead man wakened; and not a soul behind me. Her (Margaret) father's tomb commanded a side view of the church door. And on that tomb she (Margaret) sat, with her (Margaret) face covered, waylaying the holy preacher.

CHAPTER LXXXVI

THE CLOISTER AND THE HEARTH

The cool church chequered with sunbeams and crowned with heavenly purple, soothed and charmed Father Clement, as it did Margaret; and more, it carried his (Clement) mind direct to the Creator of all good and pure delights. ``MEA CULPA! MEA CULPA!'' (he)

CHAPTER LXXXIX

What that sensitive mind, and tender conscience, and loving heart, and religious soul, went through even in a few hours, under a situation so sudden and tremendous, is perhaps beyond the power of words to paint.

Fancy yourself the man; and then put yourself in his (man) place! Were I to write a volume on it, we should have to come to that at last.

``I've hit the clout; our Gerard is Vicar of Gouda.'' (the dwarf)

A very brief sketch of the dwarf's court life will suffice to prepare the reader for his (reader) own account of this feat. Some months before he (reader) went to court his (reader) intelligence had budded. He (reader) himself dated the change from a certain 8th of June, when, swinging by one hand along with the week's washing on a tight rope in the drying ground, something went crack inside his (reader) head; and lo! intellectual powers unchained. At court his (reader) shrewdness and bluntness of speech, coupled with his (reader) gigantic voice and his (reader) small stature, made him (reader) a Power: without the last item I fear they would have conducted him (reader) to that unpopular gymnasium, the gallows. The young Duchess of Burgundy, and Marie the heiress apparent, both petted him (reader), as great ladies have petted dwarfs in all ages; and the court poet melted butter by the six-foot rule, and poured enough of it down his (poet) back to stew Goliah in. He (poet) even amplified, versified, and enfeebled certain rough and ready sentences dictated by Giles.

But the dwarf reached his (dwarf) climax by a happy mixture of mind and muscle; thus:

The day before a grand court joust he (dwarf) challenged the Duke's giant to a trial of strength. This challenge made the gravest grin, and aroused expectation.

And the stars above seemed never so bright and calm.

CHAPTER XCII

Yes, the hermit of Gouda was the vicar of Gouda, and knew it not, so absolute was his (vicar) seclusion.

My reader is aware that the moment the frenzy of his (vicar) passion passed, he (vicar) was seized with remorse for having been betrayed into it. But perhaps only those who have risen as high in religious spirit as he (vicar) had, and suddenly fallen, can realize the terror at himself that took possession of him (vicar). He (vicar) felt like one whom self-confidence had betrayed to the very edge of a precipice.

``Ah, good Jerome,'' (he)
he (vicar) cried,
``how much better you knew me than I knew myself! How bitter yet wholesome was your admonition!'' (he)

Accustomed to search his (vicar) own heart, he (vicar) saw at once that the true cause of his (vicar) fury was Margaret.

``I love her (mother) then better than God,'' (he)
said he (vicar) despairingly;
``better than the Church, From such a love what can spring to me, or to her (mother)?'' (he)
He (vicar) shuddered at the thought.
``Let the strong battle temptation; `tis for the weak to flee. And who is weaker than I have shown myself? What is my penitence, my religion? A pack of cards built by degrees into a fair-seeming structure; and lo! one breath of earthly love, and it lies in the dust, I must begin again, and on a surer foundation.'' (He)
He (vicar) resolved to leave Holland at once, and spend years of his (vicar) life in some distant convent before returning to it. By that time the temptations of earthly passion would be doubly baffled; and older and a better monk, he (monk) should be more master of his (monk) earthly affections, and Margaret, seeing herself abandoned, would marry, and love another, The very anguish this last thought cost him (monk) showed the self-searcher and self-denier that he (monk) was on the path of religious duty.

But in leaving her (Margaret) for his (monk) immortal good and hers, he (monk) was not to neglect her (Margaret) temporal weal. Indeed, the sweet thought, he (monk) could make her (Margaret) comfortable for life, and rich in this world's goods, which she (Margaret) was not bound to despise, sustained him (monk) in the bitter struggle it cost him (monk) to turn his (monk) back on her (Margaret) without one kind word or look,

Another? Ah me! ah me! God and the saints to mine aid!'' (he)

How he (monk) fared on this errand has been related. But first, as you may perhaps remember, he (monk) went at night to shrive the hermit of Gouda. He (monk) found him (monk) dying, and never left him (monk) till he (monk) had closed his (monk) eyes and buried him (monk) beneath the floor of the little oratory attached to his (monk) cell. It was the peaceful end of a stormy life. The hermit had been a soldier, and even now carried a steel corselet next his (soldier) skin, saying he (soldier) was now Christ's soldier as he (soldier) had been Satan's. When Clement had shriven him (Clement) and prayed by him (Clement), he (Clement), in his (Clement) turn, sought counsel of one who was dying in so pious a frame, The hermit advised him (Clement) to be his (Clement) successor in this peaceful retreat.

``His (God) had been a hard fight against the world, the flesh, and the devil, and he (devil) had never thoroughly baffled them till he (devil) retired into the citadel of Solitude.'' (Clement/Brother Clement)

These words and the hermit's pious and peaceful death, which speedily followed, and set as it were the seal of immortal truth on them, made a deep impression upon Clement. Nor in his (Clement) case had they any prejudice to combat; the solitary recluse was still profoundly revered in the Church, whether immured as an anchorite or anchoress in some cave or cell belonging to a monastery, or hidden in the more savage but laxer seclusion of the independent hermitage. And Clement knew more about the hermits of the Church than most divines at his (Clement) time of life; he (Clement) had read much thereon at the monastery near Tergou, had devoured their lives with wonder and delight in the manuscripts of the Vatican, and conversed earnestly about them with the mendicant friars of several nations. Before Printing these friars were the great circulators of those local annals and biographies which accumulated in the convents of every land. Then his (Clement) teacher, Jerome, had been three years an anchorite on the heights of Camaldoli, where for more than four centuries the Thebaid had been revived; and Jerome, cold and curt on most religious themes, was warm with enthusiasm on this one. He (Jerome) had pored over the annals of St. John Baptist's abbey, round about which the hermit's caves were scattered, and told him (John) the names of many a noble, and many a famous warrior who had ended his (warrior) days there a hermit, and of many a bishop and archbishop who had passed from the see to the hermitage, or from the hermitage to the see. Among the former the Archbishop of Ravenna; among the latter Pope Victor the Ninth. He (Victor) told him (Victor) too, with grim delight, of their multifarious austerities, and how each hermit set himself to find where he (Victor) was weakest, and attacked himself without mercy or remission till there, even there, he (Victor) was strongest. And how seven times in the twenty-four hours, in thunder, rain, or snow, by daylight, twilight, moonlight, or torchlight, the solitaries flocked from distant points, over rugged precipitous ways, to worship in the convent church; at matins, at prime, tierce, sexte, nones, vespers, and compline. He (Victor) even, under eager questioning, described to him (Victor) the persons of famous anchorites he (Victor) had sung the Psalter and prayed with there; the only intercourse their vows allowed, except with special permission. Moncata, Duke of Moncata and Cardova, and Hidalgo of Spain, who in the flower of his (Hidalgo) youth had retired thither from the pomps, vanities, and pleasures of the world; Father John Baptist of Novara, who had led armies to battle, but was now a private soldier of Christ; Cornelius, Samuel, and Sylvanus. This last, when the great Duchess de' Medici obtained the Pope's leave, hitherto refused, to visit Camaldoli, went down and met her (Duchess) at the first wooden cross, and there, surrounded as she (Duchess) was with courtiers and flatterers, remonstrated with her (Duchess), and persuaded her (Duchess), and warned her (Duchess), not to profane that holy mountain, where no woman for so many centuries had placed her (woman) foot; and she (woman), awed by the place and the man, retreated with all her (woman) captains, soldiers, courtiers, and pages from that one hoary hermit. At Basle Clement found fresh materials, especially with respect to German and English anchorites; and he (Clement) had even prepared a

``Catena Eremitarum'' (he)
from the year of our Lord 250, when Paul of Thebes commenced his (Paul) ninety years of solitude, down to the year 1470. He (Paul) called them Angelorum amici et animalium, i.e.

FRIENDS OF ANGELS AND ANIMALS.

Thus, though in those days he (Paul) never thought to be a recluse, the road was paved, so to speak; and when the dying hermit of Gouda blessed the citadel of Solitude, where he (recluse) had fought the good fight and won it, and invited him (recluse) to take up the breast-plate of faith that now fell off his (recluse) own shrunken body, Clement said within himself:

``Heaven itself led my foot hither to this end.'' (Clement/Brother Clement)
It struck him (Clement), too, as no small coincidence that his (Clement) patron, St. Bavon, was a hermit, and an austere one, a cuirassier of the solitary cell.

As soon as he (Clement) was reconciled to Ghysbrecht Van Swieten, he (Clement) went eagerly to his (Clement) abode, praying Heaven it might not have been already occupied in these three days. The fear was not vain; these famous dens never wanted a human tenant long. He (Clement) found the rude stone door ajar; then he (Clement) made sure he (Clement) was too late; he (Clement) opened the door and went softly in. Men and women had passed that way, but none had ventured to intrude, far less to steal. Faith and simplicity had guarded that keyless door more securely than the houses of the laity were defended by their gates like a modern gaol, and think iron bars at every window, and the gentry by moat, bastion, chevaux de frise, and portcullis.

As soon as Clement was fairly in the cell there was a loud flap, and a flutter, and down came a great brown owl from a corner, and whirled out of the window, driving the air cold on Clement's face, He (Clement) started and shuddered.

Was this seeming owl something diabolical? trying to deter him (Clement) from his (Clement) soul's good? On second thoughts, might it not be some good spirit the hermit had employed to keep the cell for him (Clement), perhaps the hermit himself? Finally he (Clement) concluded that it was just an owl, and that he (Clement) would try and make friends with it.

He (Clement) kneeled down and inaugurated his (Clement) new life with prayer.

Clement had not only an earthly passion to quell, the power of which made him (Clement) tremble for his (Clement) eternal weal, but he (Clement) had a penance to do for having given way to ire, his (Clement) besetting sin, and cursed his (Clement) own brothers.

He (Clement) looked round this roomy cell furnished with so many comforts, and compared it with the pictures in his (Clement) mind of the hideous place, eremus in eremo, a desert in a desert, where holy Jerome, hermit, and the Plutarch of hermits, had wrestled with sickness, temptation, and despair four mortal years; and with the inaccessible and thorny niche, a hole in a precipice, where the boy hermit Benedict buried himself, and lived three years on the pittance the good monk Romanus could spare him (monk) from his (monk) scanty commons, and subdivided that mouthful with his (monk) friend, a raven; and the hollow tree of his (monk) patron St. Bavon; and the earthly purgatory at Fribourg, where lived a nameless saint in a horrid cavern, his (monk) eyes chilled with perpetual gloom, and his (monk) ears stunned with an eternal waterfall; and the pillar on which St. Simeon Stylita existed forty-five years; and the destina, or stone box, of St. Dunstan, where, like Hilarion in his (Dunstan) bulrush hive, sepulchro potius quam domu, he (Dunstan) could scarce sit, stand, or lie; and the living tombs, sealed with lead, of Thais, and Christina, and other recluses; and the damp dungeon of St. Alred. These and scores more of the dismal dens in which true hermits had worn out their wasted bodies on the rock, and the rock under their sleeping bodies, and their praying knees, all came into his (Dunstan) mind, and he (Dunstan) said to himself,

``This sweet retreat is for safety of the soul; but what for penance Jesu aid me against faults to come; and for the fault I rue, face of man I will not see for a twelvemonth and a day.'' (he)
He (Dunstan) had famous precedents in his (Dunstan) eye even for this last and unusual severity. In fact the original hermit of this very cell was clearly under the same vow. Hence the two apertures, through which he (Dunstan) was spoken to, and replied.

Adopting, in other respects, the uniform rule of hermits and anchorites, he (Dunstan) divided his (Dunstan) day into the seven offices, ignoring the petty accidents of light and dark, creations both of Him (Dunstan) to whom he (Dunstan) prayed so unceasingly. He (Dunstan) learned the psalter by heart, and in all the intervals of devotion, not occupied by broken slumbers, he (Dunstan) worked hard with his (Dunstan) hands. No article of the hermit's rule was more strict or more ancient than this. And here his (Dunstan) self-imposed penance embarrassed him (Dunstan), for what work could he (Dunstan) do, without being seen, that should benefit his (Dunstan) neighbours? for the hermit was to labour for himself in those cases only where his (Dunstan) subsistence depended on it. Now Clement's modest needs were amply supplied by the villagers.

On moonlight nights he (Dunstan) would steal out like a thief, and dig some poor man's garden on the outskirts of the village. He (Dunstan) made baskets and dropped them slily at humble doors.

And since he (Dunstan) could do nothing for the bodies of those who passed by his (Dunstan) cell in daytime, he (Dunstan) went out in the dead of the night with his (Dunstan) hammer and his (Dunstan) chisel, and carved moral and religious sentences all down the road upon the sandstone rocks.

``Who knows?'' (he)
said he (Dunstan),
``often a chance shaft strikes home.'' (he)

Oh, sore heart, comfort thou the poor and bereaved with holy words of solace in their native tongue; for he (Dunstan) said ``well, `tis `clavis ad corda plebis.''' Also he (man) remembered the learned Colonna had told him (Colonna) of the written mountains in the east, where kings had inscribed their victories, ``What,'' said Clement,

``are they so wise, those Eastern monarchs, to engrave their war-like glory upon the rock, making a blood bubble endure so long as earth; and shall I leave the rocks about me silent on the King of Glory, at whose word they were, and at whose breath they shall be dust? Nay, but these stones shall speak to weary wayfarers of eternal peace, and of the Lamb, whose frail and afflicted yet happy servant worketh them among.'' (ages)

Now at this time the inspired words that have consoled the poor and the afflicted for so many ages were not yet printed in Dutch, so that these sentences of gold from the holy evangelists came like fresh oracles from heaven, or like the dew on parched flowers; and the poor hermit's written rocks softened a heart Or two, and sent the heavy laden singing on their way-LRB-1-RRB-.

These holy oracles that seemed to spring up around him (Clement) like magic; his (Clement) prudent answers through his (Clement) window to such as sought ghostly counsel; and above all, his (Clement) invisibility, soon gained him (Clement) a prodigious reputation, This was not diminished by the medical advice they now and then extorted from him (Clement) sore against his (Clement) will, by tears and entreaties; for if the patients got well they gave the holy hermit the credit, and if not they laid all the blame on the devil.

``I think he (Lamb) killed nobody, for his (Lamb) remedies were womanish and weak.'' (Sage wormwood sion hyssop borage spikenard dog tongue mantle feverfew Faith all)
Sage and wormwood, sion, hyssop, borage, spikenard, dog's-tongue, our Lady's mantle, feverfew, and Faith, and all in small quantities except the last.

Then his (devil) abstinence, sure sign of a saint. The eggs and milk they brought him (devil) at first he (devil) refused with horror. Know ye not the hermit's rule is bread, or herbs, and water? Eggs, they are birds in disguise; for when the bird dieth, then the egg rotteth. As for milk, it is little better than white blood. And when they brought him (devil) too much bread he (devil) refused it. Then they used to press it on him (devil).

``Nay, holy father; give the overplus to the poor.'' (unknown)

``You who go among the poor can do that better. Is bread a thing to fling haphazard from an hermit's window?'' (unknown)
And to those who persisted after this:
``To live on charity, yet play Sir Bountiful, is to lie with the right hand. Giving another's to the poor, I should beguile them of their thanks, and cheat thee the true giver. Thus do thieves, whose boast it is they bleed the rich into the lap of the poor. Occasio avaritiae nomen pauperum.'' (the souls)

When nothing else would convince the good souls, this piece of Latin always brought them round. So would a line of Virgil's Aeneid.

This great reputation of sanctity was all external. Inside the cell was a man who held the hermit of Gouda as cheap as dirt.

``Ah!'' (he)
said he (man),
``I cannot deceive myself; I cannot deceive God's animals. See the little birds, how coy they be; I feed and feed them, and long for their friendship, yet will they never come within, nor take my hand, by lighting on't. For why? No Paul, no Benedict, no Hugh of Lincoln, no Columba, no Guthlac bides in this cell. The very owl that was here hath fled. They are not to be deceived; I have a Pope's word for that; Heaven rest his (Pope) soul.'' (he)

``Oh let mine enemy have power to scourge me with red-hot whips, to tear me leagues and leagues over rugged places by the hair of my head, as he (Pope) has served many a holy hermit, that yet baffled him (Pope) at last; to fly on me like a raging lion; to gnaw me with a serpent's fangs; any pain, any terror, but this horrible gloom of the soul that shuts me from all light of Thee and of the saints.'' ``THEY WANDERED IN THE DESERT AND PERISHED BY SERPENTS,'' (an father)
said an ancient father of hermits that went into solitude,
``and were seen no more.'' (hermits)
And another at a more recent epoch wrote: Vertuntur ad melancholiam:
``they turn to gloomy madness.'' (unknown)
These two statements, were they not one? for the ancient fathers never spoke with regret of the death of the body. No, the hermits so lost were perished souls, and the serpents were diabolical -LRB-2-RRB- thoughts, the natural brood of solitude.

St. Jerome went into the desert with three companions; one fled in the first year, two died; how? The single one that lasted was a gigantic soul with an iron body.

The cotemporary who related this made no comment, expressed no wonder, What, then, if here was a glimpse of the true proportion in every age, and many souls had always been lost in solitude for one gigantic mind and iron body that survived this terrible ordeal.

``you will not get half-way to heaven.'' (he)

Which may be thus rendered: O Christian soul, look on the wounds of the suffering One, the blood of the dying One, the price paid for our redemption! Reader, did you ever stand by the seashore after a storm, when the wind happens to have gone down suddenly? The waves cannot cease with their cause; indeed, they seem at first to the ear to lash the sounding shore more fiercely than while the wind blew. Still we are conscious that inevitable calm has begun, and is now but rocking them to sleep. So it was with those true and tempest-tossed lovers from that eventful night when they went hand in hand beneath the stars from Gouda hermitage to Gouda manse.

At times a loud wave would every now and then come roaring, but it was only memory's echo of the tempest that had swept their lives; the storm itself was over, and the boiling waters began from that moment to go down, down, down, gently, but inevitably.

This image is to supply the place of interminable details that would be tedious and tame. What best merits attention at present is the general situation, and the strange complication of feeling that arose from it. History itself, though a far more daring story-teller than romance, presents few things so strange-LRB-1-RRB- as the footing on which Gerard and Margaret now lived for many years. United by present affection, past familiarity, and a marriage irregular but legal; separated by Holy Church and by their own consciences, which sided unreservedly with Holy Church; separated by the Church, but united by a living pledge of affection, lawful in every sense at its date.

And living but a few miles from one another, and she (Margaret) calling his (Gerard) mother

``mother,'' (mother)

Catherine in these days was nearly always with her (Catherine), and Eli very often, Tergou had so little to tempt them compared with Rotterdam; and at last they left it altogether, and set up in the capital.

And thus the years glided; so barren now of striking incidents, so void of great hopes, and free from great fears, and so like one another, that without the help of dates I could scarcely indicate the progress of time.

1476 and 7 were years of great trouble to Gerard, whose conscience compelled him (Gerard) to oppose the Pope. His (Gerard) Holiness, siding with the Grey Friars in their determination to swamp every palpable distinction between the Virgin Mary and her (Mary) Son, bribed the Christian world into his (Son) crotchet by proffering pardon of all sins to such as would add to the Ave Mary this clause:

``and blessed be thy Mother Anna, from whom, without blot of sin, proceeded thy virgin flesh.'' (the Ave Mary)

Gerard, in common with many of the northern clergy, held this sentence to be flat heresy. He (Gerard) not only refused to utter it in his (Gerard) church, but warned his (Gerard) parishioners against using it in private; and he (Gerard) refused to celebrate the new feast the Pope invented at the same time, viz.,

``the feast of the miraculous conception of the Virgin.'' (the Pope)

Gerard saw this with pain, and interfered with mild but firm remonstrance; and after a considerable struggle prevailed, and got little Gerard sent to the best school in Europe, kept by one Haaghe at Deventer: this was in 1477. Many tears were shed, but the great progress the boy made at that famous school reconciled Margaret in some degree, and the fidelity of Reicht Heynes, now her (Margaret) partner in business, enabled her (Margaret) to spend weeks at a time hovering over her (Margaret) boy at Deventer.

And so the years glided; and these two persons, subjected to as strong and constant a temptation as can well be conceived, were each other's guardian angels, and not each other's tempters.

To be sure the well-greased morality of the next century, which taught that solemn vows to God are sacred in proportion as they are reasonable, had at that time entered no single mind; and the alternative to these two minds was self-denial or sacrilege.

It was a strange thing to hear them talk with unrestrained tenderness to one another of their boy, and an icy barrier between themselves all the time.

Eight years had now passed thus, and Gerard, fairly compared with men in general, was happy.

These are the principal incidents that in ten whole years befell two peaceful lives, which in a much shorter period had been so thronged with adventures and emotions.

Their general tenor was now peace, piety, the mild content that lasts, not the fierce bliss ever on tiptoe to depart, and above all, Christian charity.

On this sacred ground these two true lovers met with an uniformity and a kindness of sentiment which went far to soothe the wound in their own hearts, To pity the same bereaved; to hunt in couples all the ills in Gouda, and contrive and scheme together to remedy all that were remediable; to use the rare insight into troubled hearts which their own troubles had given them, and use it to make others happier than themselves--this was their daily practice. And in this blessed cause their passions for one another cooled a little, but their affection increased.

From this time Margaret entered heart and soul into Gerard's pious charities, that affection purged itself of all mortal dross. And as it had now long out-lived scandal and misapprehension, one would have thought that so bright an example of pure self-denying affection was to remain long before the world, to show men how nearly religious faith, even when not quite reasonable, and religious charity, which is always reasonable, could raise two true lovers' hearts to the loving hearts of the angels of heaven. But the great Disposer of events ordered otherwise.

-LRB-1-RRB- Let me not be understood to apply this to the bare outline of the relation. Many bishops and priests, and not a few popes, had wives and children as laymen; and entering orders were parted from the wives and not from the children. But in the case before the reader are the additional features of a strong surviving attachment on both sides, and of neighbourhood, besides that here the man had been led into holy orders by a false statement of the woman's death. On a summary of all the essential features, the situation was, to the best of my belief, unique.

CHAPTER XCVII

A priest is never more thoroughly a priest than in the chamber of death, Gerard did the last offices of the Church for the departed, just as he (Gerard) should have done them for his (Gerard) smallest parishioner. He (Gerard) did this mechanically, then sat down stupefied by the sudden and tremendous blow, and not yet realizing the pangs of bereavement. Then in a transport of religious enthusiasm he (Gerard) kneeled and thanked Heaven for her (Gerard) Christian end.

CHAPTER XCVIII

``How may I know, father?'' (unknown)

``Then for aught you know it may be the relic of a saint?'' (unknown)

``Certes it may be,'' (Basil)
said Basil sceptically.

``You have then broken our rule, which saith, `Put ill construction on no act done by a brother which can be construed innocently.' Who are you to judge such a man as this was? go to your cell, and stir not out for a week by way of penance.'' (He)

He (Basil) then carried off the lock of hair.

And when the coffin was to be closed, he (Basil) cleared the cell: and put the tress upon the dead man's bosom.

``There, Clement,'' (he)
said he (Basil) to the dead face. And set himself a penance for doing it; and nailed the coffin up himself.

The next day Gerard was buried in Gouda churchyard. The monks followed him (Gerard) in procession from the convent. Jerome, who was evidently carrying out the wishes of the deceased, read the service. The grave was a deep one, and at the bottom of it was a lead coffin. Poor Gerard's, light as a feather -LRB-so wasted was he (Gerard)-RRB-, was lowered, and placed by the side of it.

After the service Jerome said a few words to the crowd of parishioners that had come to take the last look at their best friend. When he (friend) spoke of the virtues of the departed loud wailing and weeping burst forth, and tears fell upon the coffin like rain.

The monks went home. Jerome collected them in the refectory and spoke to them thus:

``We have this day laid a saint in the earth. The convent will keep his (Clement) trentals, but will feast, not fast; for our good brother is freed from the burden of the flesh; his (Clement) labours are over, and he (Clement) has entered into his (Clement) joyful rest. I alone shall fast, and do penance; for to my shame I say it, I was unjust to him (Clement), and knew not his (Clement) worth till it was too late. And you, young monks, be not curious to inquire whether a lock he (Clement) bore on his (Clement) bosom was a token of pure affection or the relic of a saint; but remember the heart he (saint) wore beneath: most of all, fix your eyes upon his (saint) life and conversation, and follow them an ye may: for he (saint) was a holy man.'' (Jerome/St. Jerome)

Thus after life's fitful fever these true lovers were at peace.

The grave, kinder to them than the Church, united them for ever; and now a man of another age and nation, touched with their fate, has laboured to build their tombstone, and rescue them from long and unmerited oblivion.

He (man) asks for them your sympathy, but not your pity.

No, put this story to a wholesome use.

Fiction must often give false views of life and death. Here as it happens, curbed by history, she (them) gives you true ones. Let the barrier that kept these true lovers apart prepare you for this, that here on earth there will nearly always be some obstacle or other to your perfect happiness; to their early death apply your Reason and your Faith, by way of exercise and preparation. For if you cannot bear to be told that these died young, who had they lived a hundred years would still be dead, how shall you bear to see the gentle, the loving, and the true glide from your own bosom to the grave, and fly from your house to heaven?

Yet this is in store for you. In every age the Master of life and death, who is kinder as well as wiser than we are, has transplanted to heaven, young, earth's sweetest flowers.

I ask your sympathy, then, for their rare constancy and pure affection, and their cruel separation by a vile heresy-LRB-2-RRB- in the bosom of the Church; but not your pity for their early but happy end.

`Beati sunt qui in Domino moriuntur.

-LRB-1-RRB- He (Domino) was citing from Clement of Rome--

-LCB-ou di eautwn dikaioumetha oude dia tys ymeteras sophias, y eusebeias y ergwn wn kateirgasametha en osioteeti karthias, alla dia tys pistews-RCB-. --Epist.ad Corinth, i. 32.

-LRB-2-RRB- Celibacy of the clergy, an invention truly fiendish.

CHAPTER C

In compliance with a Custom I despise, but have not the spirit to resist, I linger on the stage to pick up the smaller fragments of humanity I have scattered about; i.e. some of them, for the wayside characters have no claim on me; they have served their turn if they have persuaded the reader that Gerard travelled from Holland to Rome through human beings, and not through a population of dolls.

Eli and Catherine lived to a great age: lived so long, that both Gerard and Margaret grew to be dim memories. Giles also was longaevous; he (Giles) went to the court of Bavaria, and was alive there at ninety, but had somehow turned into bones and leather, trumpet toned.

Cornelis, free from all rivals, and forgiven long ago by his (Giles) mother, who clung to him (Giles) more and more now all her (mother) brood was scattered, waited and waited and waited for his (Giles) parents' decease. But Catherine's shrewd word came true; ere she (Catherine) and her (Catherine) mate wore out, this worthy rusted away. At sixty-five he (mate) lay dying of old age in his (mate) mother's arms, a hale woman of eighty-six. He (mate) had lain unconscious a while, but came to himself in articulo mortis, and seeing her (woman) near him (mate), told her (woman) how he (mate) would transform the shop and premises as soon as they should be his (mate).

``Yes, my darling,'' (the woman)
said the poor old woman soothingly, and in another minute he (mate) was clay, and that clay was followed to the grave by all the feet whose shoes he (mate) had waited for.

Denys, broken-hearted at his (Denys) comrade's death, was glad to return to Burgundy, and there a small pension the court allowed him (Denys) kept him (Denys) until unexpectedly he (Denys) inherited a considerable sum from a relation. He (Denys) was known in his (Denys) native place for many years as a crusty old soldier, who could tell good stories of war when he (Denys) chose, and a bitter railer against women.

Jerome, disgusted with northern laxity, retired to Italy, and having high connections became at seventy a mitred abbot. He (abbot) put on the screw of discipline; his (abbot) monks revered and hated him (abbot). He (abbot) ruled with iron rod ten years. And one night he (abbot) died, alone; for he (abbot) had not found the way to a single heart. The Vulgate was on his (abbot) pillow, and the crucifix in his (abbot) hand, and on his (abbot) lips something more like a smile than was ever seen there while he (abbot) lived; so that, methinks, at that awful hour he (abbot) was not quite alone. Requiescat in pace. The Master he (Master) served has many servants, and they have many minds, and now and then a faithful one will be a surly one, as it is in these our mortal mansions.

The yellow-haired laddie, Gerard Gerardson, belongs not to Fiction but to History. She (abbot) has recorded his (Gerard) birth in other terms than mine. Over the tailor's house in the Brede Kirk Straet she (abbot) has inscribed:

``HAEC EST PARVA DOMUS NATUS QUA MAGNUS ERASMUS,'' (she)

and she (abbot) has written half-a-dozen lives of him (Gerard). But there is something left for her (abbot) yet to do. She (abbot) has no more comprehended magnum Erasmum, than any other pigmy comprehends a giant, or partisan a judge.

First scholar and divine of his (scholar) epoch, he (scholar) was also the heaven-born dramatist of his (scholar) century. Some of the best scenes in this new book are from his (scholar) mediaeval pen, and illumine the pages where they come; for the words of a genius so high as his (genius) are not born to die: their immediate work upon mankind fulfilled, they may seem to lie torpid; but at each fresh shower of intelligence Time pours upon their students, they prove their immortal race: they revive, they spring from the dust of great libraries; they bud, they flower, they fruit, they seed, from generation to generation, and from age to age.
